revision.text:
In [[sedimentary geology]] and fluvial [[geomorphology]], '''avulsion''' is the rapid abandonment of a river channel and the formation of a new river channel. Avulsions occur as a result of channel slopes that are much less steep than the slope that the river could travel if it took a new course.<ref name="SlingerlandSmith">{{cite journal|doi=10.1130/0091-7613(1998)026<0435:NCFAMR>2.3.CO;2|title=Necessary conditions for a meandering-river avulsion|year=1998|last1=Slingerland|first1=Rudy|last2=Smith|first2=Norman D.|journal=Geology|volume=26|pages=435–438|url=http://geology.gsapubs.org/content/26/5/435.abstract|issue=5|bibcode = 1998Geo....26..435S }}</ref>
==Deltaic and net-depositional settings==
[[Image:Mississippi Delta 1976.jpg|thumb|300px|Plumes of [[sediment]] enter the [[ocean]] from several [[river mouth|mouths]] of the [[Mississippi River]] [[bird's-foot delta]]. This sediment is responsible for building the [[River delta|delta]] and allowing it to advance into the sea. As it extends further offshore, the [[gradient (river)|channel slope]] will decrease and its bed will [[aggradation|aggrade]], promoting an avulsion.]]
Avulsions are common in [[River delta|river deltas]], where [[sediment]] [[deposition (geology)|deposits]] as the river enters the ocean and channel [[gradient]]s are typically very small.<ref>Marshak, Stephen (2001), Earth: Portrait of a Planet, New York: W.W. Norton & Company, {{ISBN|0-393-97423-5}} pp. 528–9</ref> This process is also known as '''delta switching'''.
Deposition from the river results in the formation of an individual [[deltaic lobe]] that pushes out into the sea. An example of a deltaic lobe is the bird's-foot [[River delta|delta]] of the [[Mississippi River]], pictured at right with its [[sediment]] plumes. As the deltaic lobe advances, the [[slope]] of the river channel becomes lower because the river channel is longer but has the same change in elevation (see [[slope]] or [[gradient]]). As the slope of the river channel decreases, it becomes unstable for two reasons. First, water under the force of [[gravity]] will tend to flow in the most direct course downslope. If the river could breach its natural [[levees]] (i.e., during a [[flood]]), it would spill out onto a new course with a shorter route to the ocean, thereby obtaining a more stable steeper slope.<ref name="SlingerlandSmith" /> Second, as its slope is reduced, the amount of [[shear stress]] on the bed will decrease, resulting in deposition of more sediment within the channel and thus raising of the channel bed relative to the [[floodplain]]. This will make it easier for the river to breach its levees and cut a new channel that enters the ocean at a steeper slope.
When this avulsion occurs, the new channel carries sediment out to the ocean, building a new deltaic lobe.<ref>Stanley, Steven M. (1999) Earth System History. New York: W.H. Freeman and Company, {{ISBN|0-7167-2882-6}} p. 136</ref><ref>Marshak, pp. 528–9</ref> The abandoned delta eventually subsides.<ref>Stanley, p. 136</ref>
This process is also related to the distributary network of river channels that can be observed within a river delta. When the channel does this, some of its flow can remain in the abandoned channel. When these channel switching events happen repeatedly over time, a mature delta will gain a distributary network.<ref>Easterbrook, Don J.''Surface Processes and Landforms Second Edition''Prentice Hall, New Jersey: 1999.</ref>
[[Subsidence]] of the delta and/or [[sea-level rise]] can further cause [[Backwater (river)|backwater]] and deposition in the delta. This deposition fills the channels and leaves a geologic record of channel avulsion in [[sedimentary basin]]s. On average, an avulsion will occur every time the bed of a river channel [[aggradation|aggrades]] enough that the river channel is [[wikt:camber|superelevated]] above the floodplain by one channel-depth. In this situation, enough [[hydraulic head]] is available that any breach of the natural levees will result in an avulsion.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bryant|first1=M.|last2=Falk|first2=P.|last3=Paola|first3=C.|title=Experimental study of avulsion frequency and rate of deposition|journal=Geology|date=1995|volume=23|issue=4|pages=365–368|doi=10.1130/0091-7613(1995)023<0365:ESOAFA>2.3.CO;2|bibcode=1995Geo....23..365B}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mohrig|first1=D.|last2=Heller|first2=P. L.|last3=Paola|first3=C.|last4=Lyons|first4=W. J.|title=Interpreting avulsion process from ancient alluvial sequences: Guadalope-Matarranya system (northern Spain) and Wasatch Formation (western Colorado)|journal=Geological Society of America Bulletin|date=2000|volume=112|issue=12|pages=1787–1803|doi=10.1130/0016-7606(2000)112<1787:IAPFAA>2.0.CO;2|bibcode=2000GSAB..112.1787M}}</ref>
==Erosional avulsions==
Rivers can also avulse due to the erosion of a new channel that creates a straighter path through the landscape. This can happen during large floods in situations in which the slope of the new channel is significantly greater than that of the old channel. Where the new channel's slope is about the same as the old channel's slope, a ''partial avulsion'' will occur in which both channels are occupied by flow.<ref name="SlingerlandSmith 2004">{{cite journal|last1=Slingerland|first1=Rudy|last2=Smith|first2=Norman D.|title=RIVER AVULSIONS AND THEIR DEPOSITS|journal=Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences|volume=32|pages=257|year=2004|doi=10.1146/annurev.earth.32.101802.120201|bibcode = 2004AREPS..32..257S }}</ref> An example of an erosional avulsion is the 2006 avulsion of the [[Suncook River]] in [[New Hampshire]], in which heavy rains caused flow levels to rise. The river level backed up behind an old mill dam, which produced a shallowly-sloping pool that overtopped a sand and gravel quarry, connected with a downstream section of channel, and cut a new shorter channel at 25–50 meters per hour.<ref>{{cite book|last=Perignon|first=M. C.|title=Mechanisms governing avulsions in transient landscapes: Analysis of the May 2006 Suncook River Avulsion in Epsom, New Hampshire|year=2007|publisher=[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]|type = S.B. Thesis}}</ref> Sediment mobilised by this erosional avulsion produced a depositionally-forced meander cutoff further downstream by superelevating the bed around the meander bend to nearly the level of the floodplain.<ref>{{cite book|last=Perignon|first=M. C.|title=Sediment wave-induced channel evolution following the 2006 avulsion of the Suncook River in Epsom, New Hampshire|year=2008|publisher=Massachusetts Institute of Technology|format = S.B. Thesis|url=http://dspace.mit.edu/handle/1721.1/45792}}</ref>
==Meander cutoffs==
An example of a minor avulsion is known as a [[meander cutoff]], where the high-[[sinuosity]] [[meander]] bend is abandoned in favour of the high-slope (i.e Large bending meander has river cut through a straighter course, and the meander has water drain away) This occurs when the ratio between the channel slope and the potential slope after an avulsion is less than about 1/5.<ref name="SlingerlandSmith" />
==Occurrence==
Avulsion typically occurs during large floods which carry the power necessary to rapidly change the landscape. Dam removal could also lead to avulsion.
Avulsions usually occur as a downstream to upstream process via head cutting erosion. If a bank of a current stream is breached a new trench will be cut into the existing floodplain. It either cuts through floodplain deposits or reoccupies an old channel.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Nanson | first1 = G.C. | last2 = Knighton | first2 = A.D. | year = 1996 | title = Anabranching rivers: Their cause, character, and classification | url = | journal = Earth Surface Processes and Landforms | volume = 21 | issue = 3| pages = 217–39 | doi = 10.1002/(SICI)1096-9837(199603)21:3<217::AID-ESP611>3.0.CO;2-U | bibcode = 1996ESPL...21..217N }}</ref>
Avulsions have been investigated in the deltas or coastal plain channels as a result of obstructions such as log-jams and possible tectonic influences.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Phillips|first1=J. D.|title=Log-jams and avulsions in the San Antonio River Delta, Texas|journal=Earth Surface Processes and Landforms|date=2012|volume=37|issue=9|pages=936–950|doi=10.1002/esp.3209|bibcode=2012ESPL...37..936P}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Aggradation]] * [[Alluvial fan]] * [[Lake Ragunda]] (the Ragunda event in Sweden) * [[Megafan]] * [[Meander]] * [[River delta]] * [[river plume|plume]] * [[Stream capture]]
== References == {{reflist}}
{{River morphology|state=expanded}} {{coastal geography}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Avulsion (River)}} [[Category:Geomorphology]] [[Category:Sedimentology]] [[Category:Hydraulic engineering]] [[Category:Rivers]] [[Category:Coastal geography]] [[Category:Water streams]] [[Category:Geological processes]]

revision.text:
{{short description|Between 1.8 and 0.8 billion years ago}} The '''Boring Billion''' is a term coined by palaeontologist [[Martin Brasier]] to refer to the approximately one billion-year period between 1.8 and 0.8 [[Billion years|Ga]] in Earth's history that is characterized by environmental, [[evolution]]ary, and [[Lithosphere|lithospheric]] stability.<ref name=":1" /> It has also been termed the "Barren Billion",<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|title = Precambrian supercontinents, glaciations, atmospheric oxygenation, metazoan evolution and an impact that may have changed the second half of Earth history|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1674987112000898|journal = Geoscience Frontiers|date = 2013-05-01|pages = 247–261|volume = 4|issue = 3|doi = 10.1016/j.gsf.2012.07.003|first = Grant M.|last = Young}}</ref> "Dullest Time on Earth"<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Stable isotopic compositions of carbonates from the Mesoproterozoic Bangemall group, northwestern Australia|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/000925419500049R|journal = Chemical Geology|date = 1995-06-20|pages = 153–171|volume = 123|issue = 1–4|doi = 10.1016/0009-2541(95)00049-R|first = Roger|last = Buick|first2 = David J.|last2 = Des Marais|first3 = Andrew H.|last3 = Knoll|bibcode = 1995ChGeo.123..153B}}</ref> and "Earth’s Middle Ages".<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title = Earth's middle age|url = http://geology.gsapubs.org/content/42/6/503|journal = Geology|date = 2014-06-01|issn = 0091-7613|pages = 503–506|volume = 42|issue = 6|doi = 10.1130/G35402.1|language = en|first = Peter A.|last = Cawood|first2 = Chris J.|last2 = Hawkesworth|bibcode = 2014Geo....42..503C}}</ref>
In the time leading up to the Boring Billion, Earth experienced multiple widespread [[Glacial period|glaciations]], the origin of [[Prokaryote|prokaryotic]] life, the introduction of [[oxygen]] into the atmosphere with the evolution of [[cyanobacteria]], addition of UV-blocking [[Ozone layer|ozone]] to the atmosphere, and the oxidizing of [[iron]] in the oceans.<ref name=":10">{{Cite book | year = 2011 | last = Lenton | first = Tim | last2 = Watson | first2 = Andrew | pages = 242–261 | doi = 10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199587049.003.0013 |title = Revolutions that made the Earth|isbn = 9780199587049}}</ref> After the Boring Billion, the atmosphere again underwent rapid changes as atmospheric oxygen rose to approximately modern levels, most major animal phyla evolved during the [[Cambrian explosion]], and large animals appeared in the oceans.<ref name=":10" />
By contrast, the period of the Boring Billion was characterized by [[Climate|climatic]] stability, low levels of atmospheric oxygen, lack of [[Biology|biological]] events, and the absence of extreme changes in the [[Atmosphere|atmospheric]] and [[ocean]]ic composition.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = The boring billion? – Lid tectonics, continental growth and environmental change associated with the Columbia supercontinent|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1674987113000807|journal = Geoscience Frontiers|date = 2013-11-01|pages = 681–691|volume = 4|series = Thematic Section: Antarctica – A window to the far off land|issue = 6|doi = 10.1016/j.gsf.2013.05.004|first = Nick M. W.|last = Roberts}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = The oxygenation of the atmosphere and oceans|url = http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/361/1470/903|journal = Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences|date = 2006-06-29|issn = 0962-8436|pmc = 1578726|pmid = 16754606|pages = 903–915|volume = 361|issue = 1470|doi = 10.1098/rstb.2006.1838|language = en|first = Heinrich D.|last = Holland}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|title = The rise of oxygen in Earth's early ocean and atmosphere|year=2014|journal = Nature|pages = 307–315|volume = 506|issue = 7488|doi = 10.1038/nature13068|pmid=24553238|first = Timothy W.|last = Lyons|first2 = Christopher T.|last2 = Reinhard|first3 = Noah J.|last3 = Planavsky|bibcode = 2014Natur.506..307L}}</ref> Stability during the Boring Billion may be attributed to a relatively stable [[supercontinent]] that was initiated by 1.7 Ga and persisted until its breakup around 0.75 Ga.<ref name=":10" /> The exact timing and duration of the Boring Billion is not agreed upon by scientists and estimates for the beginning and end of the Boring Billion range between 1.8 and 2.4 Ga for initiation and between 0.5 and 0.8 Ga for termination. The Boring Billion occurred during the [[Proterozoic]] Eon.
During the Boring Billion, green and purple [[Photosynthesis|photosynthetic]] [[bacteria]] appear to have thrived in an [[Anoxic waters|anoxic]] and sulfidic ocean.<ref name=":10" /> This ocean was much less productive than modern oceans, released sulfurous gasses including toxic [[hydrogen sulfide]], and was very limited in nutrients (especially [[Molybdenum|Mo]], [[Iron|Fe]], [[Nitrogen|N]], and [[Phosphorus|P]]).<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Anbar | first = A. D. | last2 = Knoll | first2 = A. H. | date = 2002-08-16 | title = Proterozoic Ocean Chemistry and Evolution: A Bioinorganic Bridge? | url = http://science.sciencemag.org/content/297/5584/1137 | journal = Science | language = en | volume = 297 | issue = 5584 | pages = 1137–1142 | doi = 10.1126/science.1069651 | issn = 0036-8075 | pmid = 12183619 | bibcode = 2002Sci...297.1137A | citeseerx = 10.1.1.615.3041 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last = Fennel | first = Katja | last2 = Follows | first2 = Mick | last3 = Falkowski | first3 = Paul G. | date = 2005-06-01 | title = The co-evolution of the nitrogen, carbon and oxygen cycles in the Proterozoic ocean | url = http://www.ajsonline.org/content/305/6-8/526 | journal = American Journal of Science | language = en | volume = 305 | issue = 6–8 | pages = 526–545 | doi = 10.2475/ajs.305.6-8.526 | issn = 0002-9599 | bibcode = 2005AmJS..305..526F }}</ref> As the Boring Billion progressed, [[eukaryotic]] life evolved from an Archean ancestor within this ocean.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal | last = Martin | first = William | last2 = Müller | first2 = Miklós | date = 1998-03-05 | title = The hydrogen hypothesis for the first eukaryote | url = http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v392/n6671/full/392037a0.html | journal = Nature | language = en | volume = 392 | issue = 6671 | pages = 37–41 | doi = 10.1038/32096 | issn = 0028-0836 | pmid=9510246 | bibcode = 1998Natur.392...37M }}</ref> By the end of the Boring Billion, the first life had appeared on land.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Horodyski | first = R. J. | last2 = Knauth | first2 = L. P. | date = 1994-01-28 | title = Life on land in the precambrian | journal = Science | volume = 263 | issue = 5146 | pages = 494–498 | doi = 10.1126/science.263.5146.494 | issn = 0036-8075 | pmid = 17754880 | bibcode = 1994Sci...263..494H }}</ref> Eukaryotes, specifically a proto-lichen, helped end the Boring Billion by causing Earth’s second oxygenation event and the [[Snowball Earth]] [[Glacial period|glaciation]] that accompanied it.<ref name=":10" />
Despite the "boring" label, when [[plate tectonics]], environmental conditions, and the [[evolution]] of eukaryotic life are considered, much was happening during this period.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.sciencenews.org/article/new-fascination-earths-boring-billion | title = New fascination with Earth's 'Boring Billion' | website = Science News | access-date = 2016-03-01 }}</ref>
== Climatic stability == [[File:Timeline showing the Boring Billion.png|thumb|700x700px|Atmospheric oxygen levels over geological time on Earth]] Recent scientific studies on the Boring Billion have found little [[evidence]] of significant climatic variability during this time period.<ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = A billion years of environmental stability and the emergence of eukaryotes: New data from northern Australia|last = Brasier|first = M.D.|date = 1998|journal = Geology|doi =10.1130/0091-7613(1998)026<0555:abyoes>2.3.co;2 |pmid = |bibcode = 1998Geo....26..555B |volume=26 |issue = 6|page=555}}</ref> Different [[Theory|theories]] have been developed by individual scientists to explain the inferred climatic stability, while others<ref name=":0" /> attribute the lack of evidence to an absence of suitable records. There is currently no generally accepted theory in the scientific community on the cause(s) of the climatic stability during the Boring Billion.
=== Tectonic constraints === The evolution of Earth’s [[biosphere]], atmosphere and [[hydrosphere]] has long been linked to the [[supercontinent cycle]], through which the Earth’s [[continental crust]] undergoes a periodic cycle of aggregation and dispersal. The period of the Boring Billion is characterized by the evolution of two different supercontinents: [[Columbia (supercontinent)|Columbia]] and [[Rodinia]]. The supercontinent Columbia [[amalgamation (geology)|amalgamated]] between 2.0 and 1.7 Ga and remained as a quasi-integral continental lid until at least 1.3 Ga. Several breakup attempts were unsuccessful. [[Geology|Geological]] and [[Paleomagnetism|paleomagnetic]] evidence suggest that Columbia underwent only minor changes to form the supercontinent Rodinia during the period from 1.1 to 0.9 Ga. [[Palaeogeography|Paleogeographic]] reconstructions suggest that the supercontinent assemblage was located in [[equator]]ial and [[Temperate climate|temperate]] climate zones throughout the intervening time frame; there is little or no evidence for continental fragments in [[Polar region|polar]] latitudes.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Reconstructing pre-Pangean supercontinents|year=2013|journal = Geological Society of America Bulletin|pages = 1735–1751|volume = 125|issue = 11–12|doi = 10.1130/b30950.1|first = D. A. D.|last = Evans|bibcode = 2013GSAB..125.1735E}}</ref> A consequence of the limited breakup history is the lack of [[passive margin]]s during the time period from 1.8 to 0.8 Ga.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Passive margins through earth history|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0012825208000871|journal = Earth-Science Reviews|date = 2008-12-01|pages = 1–26|volume = 91|issue = 1–4|doi = 10.1016/j.earscirev.2008.08.001|first = Dwight C.|last = Bradley|bibcode = 2008ESRv...91....1B}}</ref> This stable configuration provides the primary constraint on the environmental stasis that characterizes the oceans, atmosphere, and biosphere. The breakup of Rodinia at approximately 0.75 Ga is considered the end of Earth’s Boring Billion.<ref name=":1" /> It should be noted that numerous reconstructions of Columbia’s paleogeography exist and consensus has yet to be reached. Evaluating the evidence of paleo poles and continent location becomes increasingly more difficult as deposits get older and relevant rock units show increasing levels of deformation and fragmentation.<ref name=":0" />
The relative scarcity of passive margins during the Boring Billion, which are created during times of continental breakup, is proposed to support the presence of a stable continental configuration enabling environmental and climate stability during this time period.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" /> However, it is also stated in the literature that in spite of the amalgamation of the supercontinents Columbia and Rodinia, relatively stable climatological conditions during the Boring Billion are consistent with a balance between [[weathering]] intensity, [[Mantle (geology)|mantle]] [[temperature]]s and [[Solar luminosity|solar insolation]] throughout much of this time period.<ref name=":4" />
A mechanism put forward to explain low tectonic variability is related to the temperature of the [[asthenosphere]], which may have been too hot to sustain modern plate tectonics in the early stages of the Earth’s evolution. Instead of vigorous plate recycling at [[Subduction|subduction zones]], plates were linked together for billions of years until the mantle cooled off enough to further sustain plate motions and the subsequent formation of subduction zones.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.livescience.com/46366-continents-life-boring-billion-tectonics.html | title = When Slime Ruled: Evolutionary Pause Tied to Earth's Stuck Plates | year = 2014 | website = LiveScience.com | access-date = 2016-02-29 }}</ref> The onset of this component of plate tectonics may have been aided by the thickening of the [[Crust (geology)|crust]] that, once initiated, caused plate subduction to be anomalously strong.<ref name=":1" /> This process occurred around 750 Ma ago, when the crust reached a temperature low enough to initiate and sustain plate tectonics in general and subduction processes in particular.<ref name=":1" />
=== Cosmic activity === The absence of glaciation could be linked to the intensity of [[cosmic ray]] flux, and it is believed that periods of glaciation may be linked to periods with low cosmic ray flux due fluctuations in [[solar wind]] variations.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Celestial Climate Driver: A Perspective from Four Billion Years of the Carbon Cycle|url = https://journals.lib.unb.ca/index.php/GC/article/view/2691|journal = Geoscience Canada|date = 2005-03-01|issn = 1911-4850|volume = 32|issue = 1|first = Ján|last = Veizer}}</ref> Another possible cause is the rate of [[star formation]] in the [[Milky Way]]. The reduced rate in star formation may be linked to diminished glaciations from 1 to 2 Ga.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Shaviv | first = Nir J. | date = 2003-01-01 | title = The spiral structure of the Milky Way, cosmic rays, and ice age epochs on Earth | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1384107602001938 | journal = New Astronomy | volume = 8 | issue = 1 | pages = 39–77 | doi = 10.1016/S1384-1076(02)00193-8 | arxiv = astro-ph/0209252 | bibcode = 2003NewA....8...39S }}</ref>
=== Absence of prolonged glaciations === The Boring Billion as a time period is unique in a sense that it seems to lack any significant periods of prolonged glaciations that can be observed in regular periodicity in other parts of Earth's geologic history.
Some researchers<ref name=":5" /><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Glacio-epochs and the supercontinent cycle after ∼ 3.0 Ga: Tectonic boundary conditions for glaciation|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0031018207005032|journal = Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology|date = 2008-02-13|pages = 89–129|volume = 258|issue = 1–2|doi = 10.1016/j.palaeo.2007.09.021|first = Nick|last = Eyles}}</ref> believe, however, that the proposed lack of an [[ozone layer]], as expected during periods of low concentrations of atmospheric oxygen, in combination with lower solar intensity<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Palaeoclimates: the first two billion years|url = http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/361/1470/917|journal = Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences|date = 2006-06-29|issn = 0962-8436|pmc = 1868609|pmid = 16754607|pages = 917–929|volume = 361|issue = 1470|doi = 10.1098/rstb.2006.1839|language = en|first = James F.|last = Kasting|first2 = Shuhei|last2 = Ono}}</ref> during that time period should have precluded the absence of glaciation without an intense [[greenhouse effect]].
Instead, the absence of a glacial record may be a function of data infidelity rather than a real feature of geologic time. Evidence for this are old glacially cut channels, which were found in the Kimberley district of [[Western Australia]] that have been dated to 1.8 Ga.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|title = Subglacial meltwater channels and glaciofluvial deposits in the Kimberley Basin, Western Australia: 1.8 Ga low-latitude glaciation coeval with continental assembly|year=2005|journal = Journal of the Geological Society|pages = 111–124|volume = 162|issue = 1|doi = 10.1144/0016-764903-157|first = G. E.|last = Williams}}</ref>
== Low oxygen levels == Earth's geologic record indicates two events associated with significant increases in oxygen levels on Earth, with one occurring between 2.4 and 2.1 Ga, known as the [[Great Oxygenation Event]] (GOE), and the second occurring an approximate 0.8 Ga.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|title = Oxygen fluctuations stalled life on Earth|year=2014|first=Jane|last=Qiu|url = http://www.nature.com/news/oxygen-fluctuations-stalled-life-on-earth-1.15529|journal = Nature|access-date = 2017-02-24|doi=10.1038/nature.2014.15529}}</ref>
The period of time between these two oxygenations is thought to have been characterized by low levels of atmospheric oxygen (O<sub>2</sub>). Researchers postulate this widespread [[Dead zone (ecology)|anoxia]] was far greater than the anoxic [[Deep sea|deep oceans]] seen today (less than 1% of deep ocean). The cause and extent of the oxidation events and the subsequent billion years in between are subject to active debate. Although it was previously believed that atmospheric oxygen levels increased gradually through this period, new research has suggested that after the GOE – in which O<sub>2</sub> levels spiked over 1,000 fold – oxygen levels dropped significantly and remained low (with minor fluctuations) until the second oxygenation event around 0.8 Ga.<ref name=":3" /> [[File:Biogeochemical processes in the Boring Billion.png|thumb|414x414px|Biogeochemical processes in Earth's ocean during the Boring Billion. Figure taken from ''Biodiversity and Earth History'' (pg 59), by Dr. Jens Boenigk. Pyrite photo: Aquazoo, Löbbecke-Museum Düsseldorf.]]
The [[Lomagundi Excursion Event]] is considered to be the most prominent [[Isotopes of carbon|carbon isotope]] event in Earth’s history and can provide evidence for this large increase and subsequent decline in O<sub>2</sub>. For this event, a release of 10 to 20 times the current atmospheric oxygen is predicted based on levels found in the carbonate [[δ13C]] record around the time of the GOE. Suggestions in the literature point to a ‘precipitous’ drop after the Lomagundi Excursion.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Large-scale fluctuations in Precambrian atmospheric and oceanic oxygen levels from the record of U in shales|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0012821X13001520|journal = Earth and Planetary Science Letters|date = 2013-05-01|pages = 284–293|volume = 369–370|doi = 10.1016/j.epsl.2013.03.031|first = C. A.|last = Partin|first2 = A.|last2 = Bekker|first3 = N. J.|last3 = Planavsky|first4 = C. T.|last4 = Scott|first5 = B. C.|last5 = Gill|first6 = C.|last6 = Li|first7 = V.|last7 = Podkovyrov|first8 = A.|last8 = Maslov|first9 = K. O.|last9 = Konhauser|bibcode=2013E&PSL.369..284P}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Oxygen overshoot and recovery during the early Paleoproterozoic|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0012821X11007321|journal = Earth and Planetary Science Letters|date = 2012-02-01|pages = 295–304|volume = 317–318|doi = 10.1016/j.epsl.2011.12.012|first = A.|last = Bekker|first2 = H. D.|last2 = Holland|bibcode=2012E&PSL.317..295B}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Rise in seawater sulphate concentration associated with the Paleoproterozoic positive carbon isotope excursion: evidence from sulphate evaporites in the ∼2.2–2.1 Gyr shallow-marine Lucknow Formation, South Africa|journal = Terra Nova|date = 2008-04-01|issn = 1365-3121|pages = 108–117|volume = 20|issue = 2|doi = 10.1111/j.1365-3121.2008.00795.x|language = en|first = S.|last = Schröder|first2 = A.|last2 = Bekker|first3 = N. J.|last3 = Beukes|first4 = H.|last4 = Strauss|first5 = H. S.|last5 = Van Niekerk|bibcode = 2008TeNov..20..108S}}</ref> The extent to which the GOE served as a ‘Great’ oxygenation event, particularly in regards to marine environments, became a topic of discussion in the scientific community, leading [[Donald Canfield]] to develop the idea of a two billion year lag in oxygenation of the oceans. He also proposed that the ocean was characterized high levels of [[hydrogen sulfide]] during this time, creating a [[euxinic]] environment. His explanation has become known as the [[Canfield ocean|Canfield Ocean]] hypothesis. It is believed that the low and fluctuating oxygen levels that characterized the Boring Billion effectively stalled evolution of complex life for the extent of the Boring Billion. The hypothesis of a predominantly globally euxinic ocean, with low to no oxygen, supports the theory of stalled evolution of complex animals throughout the Boring Billion. Complexity is believed to have evolved at the onset of a second oxygenation event and subsequent oxygenation of the ocean between 600-800 Ba.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" />
=== Canfield ocean hypothesis === {{Main article|Canfield ocean|l1=Canfield Ocean}}
Donald Canfield proposed a hypothesis to explain how life persisted in the ocean despite low levels of oxygen.<ref name=":3" /> It is believed that during the Boring Billion, the ocean’s surface contained low levels of oxygen as a byproduct of oxygenic photosynthesis from cyanobacteria. Due to increased oxygen levels in the atmosphere, chemical weathering of the continents oxidized the mineral [[pyrite]] and transported [[sulfate]] (SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>) to the oceans.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Lyons | first = Timothy W. | last2 = Reinhard | first2 = Christopher T. | date = 2009-10-27 | title = An early productive ocean unfit for aerobics | url = http://www.pnas.org/content/106/43/18045 | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | language = en | volume = 106 | issue = 43 | pages = 18045–18046 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0910345106 | issn = 0027-8424 | pmc = 2775325 | pmid = 19846788 | bibcode = 2009PNAS..10618045L }}</ref> Through this process, the ocean became rich in [[sulfur]], and the ocean became a two layer system, consisting of a surface layer, high in oxygen, and a bottom layer, high in sulfur and low in oxygen. Canfield proposed that at the boundary between the two layers, green sulfur bacteria and purple bacteria served to convert the sulfur to [[hydrogen sulfide]] (H<sub>2</sub>S). This process of deep sea sulfide creation led to high amounts of pyrite formation during the Boring Billion, and allowed for the chemical events that enabled the evolution of animals.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Canfield | first = D. E. | date = 1998-12-03 | title = A new model for Proterozoic ocean chemistry | url = http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v396/n6710/full/396450a0.html | journal = Nature | language = en | volume = 396 | issue = 6710 | pages = 450–453 | doi = 10.1038/24839 | issn = 0028-0836 | bibcode = 1998Natur.396..450C }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Biodiversity and Earth History|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ct29BwAAQBAJ|publisher = Springer|date = 2015-03-31|isbn = 9783662463949|language = en|first = Jens|last = Boenigk|first2 = Sabina|last2 = Wodniok|first3 = Edvard|last3 = Glücksman}}</ref>
=== Johnston ocean hypothesis === Like the Canfield Ocean model, the Johnston hypothesis serves as a potential explanation of causal factors for tempered oxygenic production. The model ultimately claims that [[sulfide]] driven anoxic photosynthesis via sulfidic prokaryotes helped sustain a long period of deep ocean anoxia, and more specifically, euxinia. This period ended with the exhaustion of sulfide resources, leading to the coupling of oxygenic production and [[carbon burial]] that is characteristic of today’s oceans.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://www.pnas.org/content/106/40/16925.full.pdf?sid=72e2e6e7-5a46-4b2c-aff8-29814e23347f|title = Anoxygenic photosynthesis modulated Proterozoic oxygen and sustained Earth's middle age|last = Johnston|first = D.T.|date = 2009|journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|doi = 10.1073/pnas.0909248106 |pmid = 19805080|pmc = 2753640|access-date =|volume=106|issue = 40|pages=16925–16929|bibcode =2009PNAS..10616925J}}</ref>
At the first order, Johnson’s take on the Canfield model is to recognize that maintaining the anoxygenic conditions requisite for a billion years would be difficult: as [[organic matter]] sinks, it [[Decomposition|decays]] and consumes oxygen, a process which is exacerbated by anoxygenic photosynthesis. It has been hypothesized that an explanation for this discrepancy could be anoxygenic photosynthesis, a primary production pathway that does not involve oxygen production as a byproduct. In this case, the consumption of oxygen by [[Respiration (physiology)|respiration]] is not balanced by oxygen generation through primary production. A modern example of such a system is best exemplified in parts of the [[Black Sea]].<ref name=":3" /> [[File:Oxygen During the Boring Billion.png|left|thumb|350x350px|Research using chromium isotope analysis provides evidence for a decrease in atmospheric oxygen levels during the Boring Billion]]
=== Further evidence === Gaps in the evidence from ancient rocks have failed to explain the discrepancy between Earth’s atmospheric and oceanic oxygen levels. By tracing the movement of [[Isotopes of chromium|chromium isotopes]] from land to ocean, a process that is sensitive to atmospheric oxygen levels, the earliest signs of significant chromium oxidation have been found. This suggests levels of atmospheric oxygen to have significantly increased around 800 million years ago. Small amounts of oxygen can convert insoluble chromium, a constituent of the continental crust to a soluble form which is then transported to the ocean and deposited in [[ironstone]]. By studying the chromium isotope composition in ancient ironstones, measuring the ratio of heavier <sup>53</sup>Cr (which is more sensitive to oxidation) to the lighter <sup>52</sup>Cr, researchers can determine ancient oxygen levels. This research revealed very low oxygen levels during the Boring Billion, which are below 0.1% of present atmospheric levels.<ref name=":6" />
Rather than iron oxidation involving [[Iron(III) oxide|iron (III)]], pyrite formation (FeS<sub>2</sub>) involves the uptake of iron (II) during euxinic conditions. A research team from the University of Tasmania, under the geologist Ross Large, measured levels of pyrite in ancient [[seafloor]] rocks to show that after the initial burst of oxygen 2.4–2.1 Ga there was a decline in oxygen levels until the second oxidation event around 800–600 Ma.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web | url = http://phys.org/news/2014-02-evolution-stuck-slime-billion-years.html | title = Evolution stuck in slime for a billion years | year = 2014 | website = phys.org | access-date = 2016-02-29 }}</ref>
== Earth's first eukaryotes == In comparison to the great increase in diversity during the [[Cambrian explosion]], the evolution of life during the Boring Billion was relatively slow.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Why did evolution stall during the 'boring billion'?|year=2014|url = https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg22229672-900-why-did-evolution-stall-during-the-boring-billion/|website = New Scientist|access-date = 2016-02-23|language = en-US|first = Jeff|last = Hecht}}</ref> However, this period did see the occurrence of several major events in the history of evolution, specifically the development of [[Eukaryote|eukaryotic]] cells, the evolution of [[multicellularity]] and the [[evolution of sexual reproduction]].<ref name=":10" /> Several steps were required in the evolution of eukaryotes from a prokaryotic ancestor including a reorganization of DNA within cells and the acquisition of organelles.<ref name=":10" />
The first eukaryotes originated sometime between 2.3 and 1.1 billion years ago, around the beginning of the Boring Billion.<ref name=":10" /> The precise onset of eukaryotic evolution is hard to determine, but evidence for the presence of eukaryotic cells during this period can be found in the [[fossil]] record and molecular fossils.<ref name=":10" /> After eukaryotic cells evolved, multicellularity appeared.<ref name=":10" /> By 1.8 Ga the first living things on planet Earth that were big enough to see with the naked eye had appeared.<ref name=":10" /> By the end of the Boring Billion, multicellular algae, fungi, and animals inhabited Earth.<ref name=":10" /> Almost all of this life was restricted to Earth's oceans, but near the end of the Boring Billion the first terrestrial life, a proto-lichen, colonized land.<ref name=":10" />
=== Steps required for eukaryotic evolution === There is no agreed upon theory for the evolutionary steps that led to the appearance of the first eukaryotes, including the origin of the nucleus, cytoskeleton, and organelles that distinguish eukaryotes from prokaryotes (See "Hypotheses for the origin of eukaryotes" within the [[Eukaryote]] page). There are several changes that must have occurred as eukaryotic life evolved: an increase in genetic complexity, the development of an advanced [[cytoskeleton]], a loss of the rigid [[Cell wall|bacterial outer wall]], and the acquisition of membrane-bound [[organelle]]s within [[Cell (biology)|cells]].<ref name=":10" />
==== DNA reorganization ==== Eukaryotic cells are generally much more complex than prokaryotic cells. When eukaryotic life evolved, an increase in genetic material was necessary to enable this complexity. With an increase in the amount of genetic material inside cells as eukaryotes were evolving, the evolution of entirely new structures and mechanisms of gene copying was required, leading to the development of the eukaryotic [[cell cycle]].<ref name=":10" />
[[Histone]]s likely appeared during the Boring Billion to help organize the increasing amount of [[DNA]] in ancestral eukaryotic cells.<ref name=":10" /> DNA was packed by histones into the first [[chromosome]]s. A system of more rapid eukaryotic [[DNA replication]] in which DNA was replicated from multiple replication origins was developed so that cells containing much more genetic material would still be able to reproduce quickly.<ref name=":10" />
==== Advanced cytoskeleton ==== The development of an advanced [[cytoskeleton]] was necessary to organize the chromosomes during asexual cell [[Mitosis|replication]].<ref name=":10" /> After the loss of the rigid bacterial outer wall, the advanced cytoskeleton allowed the cells to flow and move.<ref name=":10" /> The loss of the rigid bacterial cell wall, which helped prevent water from entering the cell and diluting the cytoplasm, required ancestral eukaryotes to develop pumping mechanisms to counteract osmosis.<ref name=":10" /> Once the advanced cytoskeleton was in place and cell wall removed, ancestral eukaryotic cells had the ability to flow around and engulf other cells using the process of [[phagocytosis]], which is a more efficient way of obtaining nutrients than the system of external absorption used by prokaryotes.<ref name=":10" />
==== Acquisition of organelles (first endosymbiosis) ==== The ability to ingest other cells enabled ancestral eukaryotes to build a much more complex cell.<ref name=":10" /> Once the capacity for consuming other cells was in place, early eukaryotes began to acquire internal membrane-bound organelles that included organelles that were once free-living prokaryotes.<ref name=":10" /> Based on [[Phylogenetics|phylogenetic]] and structural evidence, it is generally accepted that [[Mitochondrion|mitochondria]] were originally derived from a free-living [[Proteobacteria|a-proteobacterium]].<ref name=":11" /> The bacterium was engulfed by an ancient cell, likely an [[Archaea]], and entered into the first [[Endosymbiosis|endosymbiotic relationship]] with its new [[Host (biology)|host]].<ref name=":11" />
Most models have explained the origin of the [[endosymbiosis]] in terms of the advantage gained by the host cell due to the greater energy production available through aerobic [[Cellular respiration|respiration]] (32 net [[Adenosine triphosphate|ATP]] vs. 2 net for [[Glycolysis cycle|glycolysis]]). However, this hypothesis has several limitations. No known organism exports ATP to its environment, making it unlikely that a bacterium would begin doing so to its host.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|title = An Overview of Endosymbiotic Models for the Origins of Eukaryotes, Their ATP-Producing Organelles (Mitochondria and Hydrogenosomes), and Their Heterotrophic Lifestyle : Biological Chemistry|year=2005|doi=10.1515/BC.2001.187 |pmid=11767942|first1=William|last1=Martin |first2=Meike |last2=Hoffmeister |first3=Carmen |last3=Rotte |first4=Katrin |last4=Henze |url = http://www.degruyter.com/view/j/bchm.2001.382.issue-11/bc.2001.187/bc.2001.187.xml|journal = Biological Chemistry|volume=382|issue=11|pages=1521–39|access-date = 2016-02-24}}</ref> In addition, some eukaryotes possess mitochondria-derived [[organelle]]s called [[hydrogenosome]]s which perform a type of anaerobic respiration, suggesting an adaptation to an anoxic environment.<ref name=":9" /> An alternative explanation known as the Hydrogen Hypothesis suggests that the unique conditions of the Canfield Ocean may have exerted a positive selective pressure on mitochondria for reasons unrelated to aerobic respiration. According to the Hydrogen Hypothesis, the original endosymbiotic event was between a hydrogen-producing bacterium and a hydrogen-consuming [[Archaea|archaeon]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|title = Energy metabolism among eukaryotic anaerobes in light of Proterozoic ocean chemistry|url = http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/363/1504/2717|journal = Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences|date = 2008-08-27|issn = 0962-8436|pmc = 2606767|pmid = 18468979|pages = 2717–2729|volume = 363|issue = 1504|doi = 10.1098/rstb.2008.0031|language = en|first = Marek|last = Mentel|first2 = William|last2 = Martin}}</ref> This symbiosis would have been advantageous in the anoxic conditions in the deeper reaches of the oceans at that time and would explain the widespread phylogenetic distribution of anaerobic respiration genes among eukaryotes.<ref name=":2" /> One other hypothesis is that a sulfur-metabolizing archaea and the ancestor of mitochondria lived in proximity, each feeding on the other's waste products and deriving energy through the recycling of [[sulfur]].<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Searcy|first=Dennis G.|last2=Hixon|first2=William G.|date=1991-01-01|title=Cytoskeletal origins in sulfur-metabolizing archaebacteria|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0303264791900089|journal=Biosystems|series=Papers presented at the 8th Biennial Conference of the International Society for Evolutionary Protistology|volume=25|issue=1–2|pages=1–11|doi=10.1016/0303-2647(91)90008-9|pmid=1906756}}</ref> When environmental conditions became harsh for one partner, the energy generation and recycling system became internalized and the archaeon and ancestral mitochondria fused to form one organism.<ref name=":13" />
[[Chloroplast]]s are also considered endosymbionts and were likely acquired during the Boring Billion in the same manner as mitochondria.<ref name=":10" /> It is generally accepted that chloroplasts are descendants of a free-living oxygen-producing [[cyanobacteria]].<ref name=":10" />
=== Fossil evidence for eukaryotic evolution === While it is unknown how the first eukaryotes evolved, they first appear in the fossil record by 1.85 Ga.<ref name=":10" />
[[Acritarch]]s, whose name means ‘uncertain origin’, are tiny, roughly spherical fossils present from before 2 billion years ago and throughout the Boring Billion that cannot be convincingly assigned to any particular part of the tree of life.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Zang | first = Wen-Long | date = 2007-06-20 | title = Deposition and deformation of late Archaean sediments and preservation of microfossils in the Harris Greenstone Domain, Gawler Craton, South Australia | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301926807000642 | journal = Precambrian Research | volume = 156 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 107–124 | doi = 10.1016/j.precamres.2007.03.002 | bibcode = 2007PreR..156..107Z }}</ref> One interpretation of acritarchs is that they represent the resting stage, or [[cyst]]s, of eukaryotic [[algae]].<ref name=":10" /> However, since [[bacteria]] are also known to cysts and spores, a [[prokaryote]] origin can’t be ruled out. It is generally agreed by experts on fossil life that acritarchs from about 1.85 Ga and later represent eukaryotes.<ref name=":10" />
Larger two centimeter, 2.1 billion year old spiral fossils found in a mine in Michigan are grouped into the [[Grypania]], a grouping of spiral fossils previously thought to have arisen 1.4–1.6 billion years ago.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Megascopic eukaryotic algae from the 2.1-billion-year-old negaunee iron-formation, Michigan|url = http://science.sciencemag.org/content/257/5067/232|journal = Science|date = 1992-07-10|issn = 0036-8075|pmid = 1631544|pages = 232–235|volume = 257|issue = 5067|doi = 10.1126/science.1631544|language = en|first = T. M.|last = Han|first2 = B.|last2 = Runnegar|bibcode = 1992Sci...257..232H}}</ref> Traces of internal detail confirm that the younger Grypania fossils are eukaryotes, but the older spirals lack fine detail and may have been made by filaments of prokaryote cells.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Neoproterozoic fossils from the Franklin Mountains, northwestern Canada: stratigraphic and palaeobiological implications|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S030192680000142X|journal = Precambrian Research|date = 2001-04-02|pages = 235–251|volume = 107|issue = 3–4|doi = 10.1016/S0301-9268(00)00142-X|first = Joakim|last = Samuelsson|first2 = Nicholas J|last2 = Butterfield|bibcode = 2001PreR..107..235S}}</ref> The older fossils were possibly also incorrectly dated and have a more accurate age of 1.8–1.9 billion years.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Age of volcanic rocks and syndepositional iron formations, Marquette Range Supergroup: implications for the tectonic setting of Paleoproterozoic iron formations of the Lake Superior region|url = http://cjes.geoscienceworld.org/content/39/6/999|journal = Canadian Journal of Earth Sciences|date = 2002-06-01|issn = 0008-4077|pages = 999–1012|volume = 39|issue = 6|doi = 10.1139/e02-016|language = en|first = D. A.|last = Schneider|first2 = M. E.|last2 = Bickford|first3 = W. F.|last3 = Cannon|first4 = K. J.|last4 = Schulz|first5 = M. A.|last5 = Hamilton|bibcode = 2002CaJES..39..999S}}</ref>
=== Molecular fossil evidence for eukaryotic evolution === Steranes, the traces of [[sterols]] used in construction of the [[membrane]]s of eukaryotes, have been found in 2.7 billion year old [[shale]]s, and are evidence that eukaryotes, or at least their metabolic ancestors, were present at that time.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Archean Molecular Fossils and the Early Rise of Eukaryotes|url = http://science.sciencemag.org/content/285/5430/1033|journal = Science|date = 1999-08-13|issn = 0036-8075|pmid = 10446042|pages = 1033–1036|volume = 285|issue = 5430|doi = 10.1126/science.285.5430.1033|language = en|first = Jochen J.|last = Brocks|first2 = Graham A.|last2 = Logan|first3 = Roger|last3 = Buick|first4 = Roger E.|last4 = Summons|citeseerx = 10.1.1.516.9123}}</ref> While the sterols found in these shales are not made by any known modern bacteria, some bacteria are capable of producing sterols. Therefore, sterane presence is not definite evidence of eukaryotic cells.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Phylogenetic and biochemical evidence for sterol synthesis in the bacterium Gemmata obscuriglobus|last = Pearson|first = Ann|date = 2003|journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|doi = 10.1073/pnas.2536559100|pmid =14660793|volume=100|issue = 26|pages=15352–15357|pmc=307571|bibcode=2003PNAS..10015352P}}</ref>
== Eukaryotic diversification == After the first eukaryotes appeared, the diversification and evolution of eukaryotes proceeded slowly.<ref name=":10" /> Environmental conditions, especially the presence of toxic sulfide, lack of oxygen in ocean water, lack of key nutrients and [[trace metal]]s in ocean water, and/or little tectonic activity, contributed to slow eukaryotic evolution.<ref name=":1" /> Low oxygen levels in ocean water during the Boring Billion may have kept eukaryotes in low numbers and prevented the evolution of large energy hungry, fast moving animals that evolved at the end of the Boring Billion,<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|title = Low Mid-Proterozoic atmospheric oxygen levels and the delayed rise of animals|url = http://science.sciencemag.org/content/346/6209/635|journal = Science|date = 2014-10-31|issn = 0036-8075|pmid = 25359975|pages = 635–638|volume = 346|issue = 6209|doi = 10.1126/science.1258410|language = en|first = Noah J.|last = Planavsky|first2 = Christopher T.|last2 = Reinhard|first3 = Xiangli|last3 = Wang|first4 = Danielle|last4 = Thomson|first5 = Peter|last5 = McGoldrick|first6 = Robert H.|last6 = Rainbird|first7 = Thomas|last7 = Johnson|first8 = Woodward W.|last8 = Fischer|first9 = Timothy W.|last9 = Lyons|bibcode = 2014Sci...346..635P}}</ref> though it has been argued that even with very little oxygen, animals could have emerged and persevered.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Oxygen and animal evolution: Did a rise of atmospheric oxygen "trigger" the origin of animals?|journal = BioEssays|date = 2014-12-01|issn = 1521-1878|pages = 1145–1155|volume = 36|issue = 12|doi = 10.1002/bies.201400101|language = en|first = Daniel B.|last = Mills|first2 = Donald E.|last2 = Canfield|pmid=25244426}}</ref> It is also known that diversification of eukaryotes began well before the onset of global [[Oxygenation (environmental)|oxygenation]] of the oceans, leading to the conclusion that [[Anoxic waters|anoxic]] conditions could not be the only cause of slow eukaryotic evolution.<ref name=":10" />
The anoxic and euxinic conditions of the period would also have affected the abundance of certain nutrients and trace metals in the environment. Both anoxic and sulfidic conditions lead to decreased [[solubility]] of iron,<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Canfield | first = Donald | date = December 3, 1998 | title = A new model for Proterozoic ocean chemistry | url = | journal = Nature | doi = | pmid = }}</ref> while sulfidic conditions lead to increased precipitation of the trace metal [[molybdenum]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Reinhard | first = Christopher T. | last2 = Planavsky | first2 = Noah J. | last3 = Robbins | first3 = Leslie J. | last4 = Partin | first4 = Camille A. | last5 = Gill | first5 = Benjamin C. | last6 = Lalonde | first6 = Stefan V. | last7 = Bekker | first7 = Andrey | last8 = Konhauser | first8 = Kurt O. | last9 = Lyons | first9 = Timothy W. | date = 2013-04-02 | title = Proterozoic ocean redox and biogeochemical stasis | url = http://www.pnas.org/content/110/14/5357 | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | language = en | volume = 110 | issue = 14 | pages = 5357–5362 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.1208622110 | issn = 0027-8424 | pmc = 3619314 | pmid = 23515332 | bibcode = 2013PNAS..110.5357R }}</ref> Both of these metals are essential for the utilization of nitrogen, as they are necessary for the [[enzyme]]s nitrate reductase, which reduced nitrate and nitrite to ammonia, and nitrogenase, which reduces atmospheric nitrogen to nitrate.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal | last = Anbar | first = A.D. | date = August 16, 2002 | title = Proterozoic ocean chemistry and evolution: a bioinorganic bridge | url = | journal = Science | doi = | pmid = }}</ref> As such, life in the Proterozoic would have suffered from a lack of nitrogen, a situation which would have competitively favored prokaryotes over eukaryotes and likely negatively affected eukaryotic evolution.<ref name=":8" />
Despite these environmental constraints, eukaryotes developed multicellularity during the Boring Billion and a major diversification of eukaryotes occurred at the supergroup level between 1.9 and 0.75 Ga.<ref name=":10" /> Key biological innovations such as cell differentiation, [[Evolution of sexual reproduction|sexual reproduction]], and eukaryotic [[photosynthesis]] separated eukaryotes into [[animal]]s, [[algae]], and [[Fungus|fungi]].<ref name=":10" />
=== Multicellularity === The evolution of cell [[Chemical polarity|polarity]], which allows cells to send a molecular message to one side of the cell but not the other and to interact with nearby cells, allowed the development of organized multicellularity during the Boring Billion.<ref name=":10" /> Qingshania, a small spiral coil that appears in the fossil record 1.7 Ga, is the oldest known fossil multicellular eukaryote.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Significance of eukaryotic organisms in the microfossil flora of Changeheng system|last = Yan|first = Y|date = 1993|journal = Acta Micropalaeontologica Sinica|doi = |pmid = }}</ref>
=== Cellular differentiation and sexual reproduction === The much larger eukaryotic genome with its rapid copying gave eukaryotes the capacity to create many different types of cells and assemble them together into large, complex, multicellular life.<ref name=":10" /> By 1.2 Ga, [[meiosis]] and sexual reproduction are present in single-celled eukaryotes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.novapublishers.com/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=31918|title=DNA Repair as the Primary Adaptive Function of Sex in Bacteria and Eukaryotes pp. 1-50|website=www.novapublishers.com|access-date=2016-03-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029202307/https://www.novapublishers.com/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=31918#|archive-date=2013-10-29|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> ''Bangiomorpha pubescens,'' a fossil multicellular red algae from the 1.2 Ga Hunting Formation, is the first known sexually reproducing organism. Fossils show differential spore/gamete formation, which is also evidence of [[cellular differentiation]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Butterfield|first=Nicholas J.|date=2000-06-20|title=Bangiomorpha pubescens n. gen., n. sp.: implications for the evolution of sex, multicellularity, and the Mesoproterozoic/Neoproterozoic radiation of eukaryotes|url=http://paleobiol.geoscienceworld.org/content/26/3/386|journal=Paleobiology|language=en|volume=26|issue=3|pages=386–404|doi=10.1666/0094-8373(2000)026<0386:bpngns>2.0.co;2|issn=0094-8373}}</ref>
=== First algae === The first algae split from ancestral eukaryotes about 1.4 Ga.<ref name=":10" /> Molecular clock evidence suggests that red and green algae had separated by 1.2-0.9 Ga.<ref name=":10" />
=== First fungi === From molecular clock dating of [[DNA]] and fossil evidence, the divergence of animals and fungi occurred between 1.2 and 1.9 billion years ago.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Heckman|first=Daniel S.|last2=Geiser|first2=David M.|last3=Eidell|first3=Brooke R.|last4=Stauffer|first4=Rebecca L.|last5=Kardos|first5=Natalie L.|last6=Hedges|first6=S. Blair|date=2001-08-10|title=Molecular Evidence for the Early Colonization of Land by Fungi and Plants|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/293/5532/1129|journal=Science|language=en|volume=293|issue=5532|pages=1129–1133|doi=10.1126/science.1061457|issn=0036-8075|pmid=11498589}}</ref> 1.43 Ga fossils named ''Tappania'' may represent the first [[Fungus|fungi]].<ref name=":10" /> These 0.1 mm fossils of branching irregular cells have an obvious [[cytoskeleton]] and bulbous [[protrusion]]s that suggest vegetative reproduction by [[budding]].<ref name=":10" /> ''Tappania'' fossils dated near the end of the Boring Billion 0.9-0.8 billion years ago show definite multi-cellularity and differentiation.<ref name=":10" /> Some branches that extend from cells appear to re-fuse together, forming net-like patterns.<ref name=":10" /> This is a characteristic of fungi, whose hair-like [[hypha]]e extending from their cells sometimes fuse in this manner.<ref name=":10" />
== First life on land == Plants do not appear on land until 0.47 Ga, but around the end of the Boring Billion (0.7–0.9 Ga) land was beginning to be colonized by cyanobacteria and proto-lichens.<ref name=":10" />
Proto-lichens were [[Symbiosis|symbionts]] between fungi and algae and left evidence of biological weathering of continental rock in the [[Doushantuo Formation|Doushantuo]] [[phosphorite]] formation (0.6 Ga)<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anbar|first=A. D.|last2=Knoll|first2=A. H.|date=2002-08-16|title=Proterozoic Ocean Chemistry and Evolution: A Bioinorganic Bridge?|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/297/5584/1137|journal=Science|language=en|volume=297|issue=5584|pages=1137–1142|doi=10.1126/science.1069651|issn=0036-8075|pmid=12183619|bibcode=2002Sci...297.1137A|citeseerx=10.1.1.615.3041}}</ref> and in [[laterite]]s, Earth's first soils.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Neaman|first=Alexander|last2=Chorover|first2=Jon|last3=Brantley|first3=Susan L.|date=2005-02-01|title=Element mobility patterns record organic ligands in soils on early Earth|url=http://geology.gsapubs.org/content/33/2/117|journal=Geology|language=en|volume=33|issue=2|pages=117–120|doi=10.1130/G20687.1|issn=0091-7613|bibcode=2005Geo....33..117N}}</ref> Additional evidence for life on land is the characteristic carbon isotope signature of photosynthesis that is recorded in rock crusts and ancient soils from the end of the Boring Billion.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Horodyski|first=R. J.|last2=Knauth|first2=L. P.|date=1994-01-28|title=Life on land in the precambrian|journal=Science|volume=263|issue=5146|pages=494–498|doi=10.1126/science.263.5146.494|issn=0036-8075|pmid=17754880|bibcode=1994Sci...263..494H}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Retallack|first=Gregory J.|last2=Mindszenty|first2=Andrea|date=1994-04-01|title=Well preserved late Precambrian Paleosols from Northwest Scotland|url=http://jsedres.geoscienceworld.org/content/64/2a/264|journal=Journal of Sedimentary Research|language=en|volume=64|issue=2a|pages=264–281|doi=10.1306/D4267D7A-2B26-11D7-8648000102C1865D|issn=1527-1404}}</ref> Terrestrial microfossils and [[microbial mat]]s of cyanobacteria have also been preserved.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Watanabe|first=Yumiko|last2=Martini|first2=Jacques E. J.|last3=Ohmoto|first3=Hiroshi|date=2000-11-30|title=Geochemical evidence for terrestrial ecosystems 2.6 billion years ago|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v408/n6812/abs/408574a0.html|journal=Nature|language=en|volume=408|issue=6812|pages=574–578|doi=10.1038/35046052|issn=0028-0836|pmid=11117742|bibcode=2000Natur.408..574W}}</ref> Some microbial communities lived under rock surfaces, others bound sand together, and some sat atop soils.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://risweb.st-andrews.ac.uk/portal/da/researchoutput/life-on-land-in-the-proterozoic-evidence-from-the-torridonian-rocks-of-northwest-scotland(b8c702c9-ba95-4ac8-b78c-84293f17881d).html|title=Life on land in the Proterozoic: Evidence from the Torridonian rocks of northwest Scotland |volume=30 |issue=9 |pages=811 |journal=Geology|year=2002|doi=10.1130/0091-7613(2002)030<0811:LOLITP>2.0.CO;2|first=Anthony Robert|last=Prave|access-date=2016-03-05|bibcode=2002Geo....30..811P}}</ref>
