revision.comment: Disambiguate [[Kirchhoff's laws (disambiguation)]] to [[Kirchhoff's circuit laws]] using [[:en:Wikipedia:Tools/Navigation_popups|popups]]
revision.text:
{{expert-subject|date=December 2014|reason=Needs to be integrated with existing physics coverage.}}
The '''electrokinematics theorem'''<ref>Pellegrini, B. (1986), "Electric charge motion, induced current, energy balance, and noise", Phys. Rev. B 34: 5921-5924.</ref><ref name="note2">Pellegrini, B.(1993), "Extension of the electrokinematics theorem to the electromagnetic field and quantum mechanics", Il Nuovo Cimento 15 D: 855–879.</ref><ref name="note3">Pellegrini, B.(1993), "Elementary application of quaantum-electrokinematics theorem to the electromagnetic field and quantum mechanics", Il Nuovo Cimento 15 D: 881-896.</ref> connects the velocity and the [[Electric charge|charge]] of [[Charge carrier|carriers]] moving inside an arbitrary volume to the currents, voltages and power on its surface through an arbitrary [[Conservative vector field#Irrotational vector fields|irrotational vector]]. Since it contains, as a particular application, the [[Shockley–Ramo theorem|Ramo-Shockley theorem]],<ref>Ramo, S.(1939), "Currents induced by electron motion", Proc. IRE 27: 584–585.</ref><ref>Shockley, W. (1938), Currents to conductors induced by a moving point charge, J. App. Phys. 9: 635-636.</ref> the electrokinematics theorem is also known as '''Ramo-Shockly-Pellegrini theorem'''.
==Statement== To introduce the electrokinematics theorem let us first list a few definitions: ''q<sub>j</sub>'', ''r<sub>j</sub>'' and ''v<sub>j</sub>'' are the electric charge, position and velocity, respectively, at the time t of the ''j''th charge carrier; <math>A_{0}</math>, <math>E=-\nabla A_{0}</math> and <math>\varepsilon</math> are the [[electric potential]], [[Electric field|field]], and [[Electric permittivity|permittivity]], respectively, <math>J_{q}</math>, <math>J_{d}=\varepsilon \partial E/ \partial t</math> and <math>J=J_{q}+J_{d}</math> are the conduction, displacement and, in a 'quasi-electrostatic' assumption, total current density, respectively; <math>F=-\nabla \Phi</math> is an arbitrary irrotational vector in an arbitrary volume <math>\Omega</math> enclosed by the surface S, with the constraint that <math>\nabla (\varepsilon F)=0</math>. Now let us integrate over <math>\Omega</math> the scalar product of the vector <math>F</math> by the two members of the above-mentioned current equation. Indeed, by applying the divergence theorem, the vector identity <math>a\cdot\nabla\gamma=\nabla\cdot(\gamma a)-\gamma\nabla\cdot a</math>, the above-mentioned constraint and the fact that <math>\nabla\cdot J=0</math>, we obtain the electrokinematics theorem in the first form
:<math>-\int_{S} \Phi J\cdot dS=\int_{\Omega}J_{q}\cdot Fd^{3}r-\int_{S}\varepsilon\frac{\partial A_{0}}{\partial t}F\cdot dS</math> ,
which, taking into account the corpuscular nature of the current <math>J_{q}=\sum_{j=1}^{N(t)} q_{j}\delta(r-r_{j})v_{j}</math>, where <math>\delta(r-r_{j})</math> is the [[Dirac delta function]] and ''N(t)'' is the carrier number in <math>\Omega</math> at the time ''t'', becomes
:<math>-\int_{S} \Phi J\cdot dS=\sum_{j=1}^{N(t)} q_{j}v_{j}\cdot F(r_{j})-\int_{S}\varepsilon\frac{\partial A_{0}}{\partial t}F\cdot dS</math> .
A component <math>A_{Vk}[r,V_{k}(t)]=V_{k}(t)\psi_{k}(r)</math> of the total electric potential <math>A_{0}=A_{Vk}+A_{qj}</math> is due to the voltage <math>V_{k}(t)</math> applied to the ''k''th electrode on ''S'', on which <math>\psi_{k}(r)=1</math> (and with the other boundary conditions <math>\psi_{k}(r)=\psi_{k}(\infty)=0</math> on the other electrodes and for <math>r \to \infty</math>), and each component <math>A_{qj}[r,r_{j}(t)]</math> is due to the ''j''th charge carrier ''q<sub>j</sub>'' , being <math>A_{qj}[r,r_{j}(t)]=0</math> for <math>r</math> and <math>r_j(t)</math> over any electrode and for <math>r \to \infty</math>. Moreover, let the surface ''S'' enclosing the volume <math>\Omega</math> consist of a part <math>S_{E}=\sum_{k=1}^{n}S_{k}</math> covered by ''n'' electrodes and an uncovered part <math>S_R</math>.
According to the above definitions and boundary conditions, and to the [[superposition theorem]], the second equation can be split into the contributions
:<math>-\int_{S_{E}} \Phi J_{q}\cdot dS=\sum_{j=1}^{N(t)} q_{j}v_{j}\cdot F(r_{j})+\sum_{j=1}^{M(t)}\int_{S_{R}}\varepsilon(\Phi\frac{\partial E_{j}}{\partial t}-\frac{\partial A_{qj}}{\partial t}F)\cdot dS</math> ,
:<math>-\int_{S_{E}} \Phi J_{V}\cdot dS=\sum_{k=1}^n \int_{S_{R}}\varepsilon \Phi \frac{\partial E_{k}}{\partial t} \cdot dS-\sum_{k=1}^n \int_{S}\varepsilon \frac{\partial A_{Vk}}{\partial t} F\cdot dS</math>,
relative to the carriers and to the electrode voltages, respectively, <math>M(t)</math> being the total number of carriers in the space, inside and outside <math>\Omega</math>, at time ''t'', <math>E_{j}=-\nabla A_{qj}</math> and <math>E_{k}=-\nabla A_{Vk}</math>. The integrals of the above equations account for the displacement current, in particular across <math>S_R</math>.
==Current and capacitance==
One of the more meaningful application of the above equations is to compute the current
:<math>i_{h}\equiv-\int_{S_{h}}J\cdot dS=i_{qh}+i_{Vh}</math> ,
through an ''h''th electrode of interest corresponding to the surface <math>S_{h}</math>, <math>i_{qh}</math> and <math>i_{Vh}</math> being the current due to the carriers and to the electrode voltages, to be computed through third and fourth equations, respectively.
===Open devices===
Let us consider as a first example, the case of a surface ''S'' that is not completely covered by electrodes, i.e., <math>S_{R} \ne 0</math>, and let us choose [[Dirichlet boundary conditions]] <math>\Phi=\Phi_{h}=1</math> on the ''h''th electrode of interest and of <math>\Phi_{h}=0</math> on the other electrodes so that, from the above equations we have
:<math>i_{qh}=\sum_{j=1}^{N(t)}q_{j}v_{j}\cdot F_{h}(r_{j})+\sum_{j=1}^{M(t)}\int_{S_{R}}\varepsilon(\Phi_{h}\frac{\partial E_{j}}{\partial t}-\frac{\partial A_{qj}}{\partial t}F_{h})\cdot dS=</math>
:<math>i_{dh}=\sum_{k=1}^{n}C_{hk}\frac{dV_{k}}{dt}</math> ,
where <math>F=F_{h}(r_{j})</math> is relative to the above-mentioned boundary conditions and <math>C_{hk}</math> is a capacitive coefficient of the ''h''th electrode given by
:<math>C_{hk}=-(\int_{S_{k}}\varepsilon F_{h}\cdot dS+\int_{S_{R}}\varepsilon(\Phi_{h}\nabla\psi_{k}+\psi_{k}F_{h})\cdot dS)</math> .
<math>V_{h}</math> is the voltage difference between the ''h''th electrode and an electrode held to a constant voltage (DC), for instance, directly connected to ground or through a DC voltage source. The above equations hold true for the above Dirichlet conditions for <math>\Phi_h</math> and for any other choice of boundary conditions on <math>S_R</math>.
A second case can be that in which <math>\Phi_{h}=0</math> also on <math>S_R</math> so that such equations reduce to
:<math>i_{qh}=\sum_{j=1}^{N(t)}q_{j}v_{j}\cdot F_h(r_{j})-\sum_{j=1}^{M(t)}\int_{S_{R}}\varepsilon\frac{\partial A_{0j}}{\partial t}F_{h}\cdot dS</math> ,
:<math>C_{hk}=-(\int_{S_{k}}\varepsilon F_{h}\cdot dS+\int_{S_{R}}\varepsilon\Psi_{k}F_{h}\cdot dS)</math> .
As a third case, exploiting also to the arbitrariness of <math>S_R</math> , we can choose a [[Neumann boundary condition]] of <math>F_{h}</math> tangent to <math>S_R</math> in any point. Then the equations become
:<math>i_{qh}=\sum_{j=1}^{N(t)}q_{j}v_{j}\cdot F_{h}(r_{j})-\sum_{j=1}^{M(t)}\int_{S_{R}}\varepsilon\Phi_{h}\frac{\partial E_{j}}{\partial t}\cdot dS</math> ,
:<math>C_{hk}=-(\int_{S_{k}}\varepsilon F_{h}\cdot dS+\int_{S_{R}}\varepsilon\nabla\Psi_{h}\cdot dS)</math> .
In particular, this case is useful when the device is a right parallelepiped, being <math>S_R</math> and <math>S_E</math> the lateral surface and the bases, respectively.
As a fourth application let us assume <math>\Phi=1</math> in the whole the volume <math>\Omega</math>, i.e., <math>F=0</math> in it, so that from the first equation of Section 1 we have
:<math>\sum_{h=1}^{n}i_{h}-\int_{S_{R}}\varepsilon(\sum_{j=1}^{M(t)}\frac{\partial E_{j}}{\partial t}+\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{\partial E_{k}}{\partial t})\cdot dS=0</math> ,
which recover the [[Kirchhoff's circuit laws|Kirchhoff law]] with the inclusion the displacement current across the surface <math>S_R</math> that is not covered by electrodes.
===Enclosed devices===
A fifth case, historically significant, is that of electrodes that completely enclose the volume <math>\Omega</math> of the device, i.e. <math>S_{R}=0</math> . Indeed, choosing again the Dirichlet boundary conditions of <math>\Phi_{h}=1</math> on <math>S_h</math> and <math>\Phi_{h}=0</math> on the other electrodes, from the equations for the open device we get the relationships
:<math>i_{h}=\sum_{j=1}^{N(t)}q_{j}v_{j}\cdot F_h(r_{j})+\sum_{k=1}^{n}C_{hk}\frac{dV_h}{dt}</math> ,
with
:<math>C_{hk}=-\int_{S_k}\varepsilon F_{h}\cdot dS</math> ,
thus obtaining the Ramo-Shockly theorem as a particular application of the electrokinematics theorem, extended from the vacuum devices to any electrical component and material.
As the above relationships hold true also when <math>F(t)</math> depends on time, we can have a sixty application if we select as <math>F=F_{V}=-\sum_{k=1}^{n}V_{k}(t)\nabla\psi_{k}(r)</math> the electric field generated by the electrode voltages when there is no charge in <math>\Omega</math>. Indeed, as the first equation can be written in the form
:<math>-\int_{S}\Phi J\cdot dS=\int_{\Omega}J\cdot Fd^{3}r</math> ,
from which we have
:<math>\sum_{h=1}^{n}V_{h}i_{h}=\int_{\Omega}J\cdot F_{V}d^{3}r\equiv W</math>,
where <math>W</math> corresponds to the power entering the device <math>\Omega</math> across the electrodes (enclosing it). On the other side
:<math>\int_{\Omega}(E\cdot J_{q}+E\cdot \frac{\varepsilon \partial E}{\partial t})d^{3}r=\int_{\Omega}E\cdot Jd^{3}r\equiv \frac{d\Xi}{dt}</math> ,
gives the increment of the internal energy <math>\Xi</math> in <math>\Omega</math> in a unit of time, <math>E=F_{V}+E_{q}</math> being the total electric field of which <math>F_{V}</math> is due the electrodes and <math>E_{q}=-\nabla \psi_{q}(r,t)</math> is due to the whole charge density in <math>\Omega</math> with <math>\psi_{q}(r,t)=0</math> over ''S''. Then it is <math>\int_{\Omega}E_{q}\cdot Jd^{3}r=0</math>, so that, according to such equations, we also verify the energy balance <math>W=d\Xi/dt</math> by means of the electrokinematics theorem. With the above relationships the balance can be extended also to the open devices by taking into account the displacement current across <math>S_R</math>.
==Fluctuations==
A meaningful application of the above results is also the computation of the fluctuations of the current <math>i_{h}=i_{qh}</math> when the electrode voltages is constant, because this is useful for the evaluation of the device [[Noise (electronics)|noise]]. To this end, we can exploit the first equation of section [[#Open devices|Open devices]], because it concerns the more general case of an open device and it can be reduced to a more simply relationship. This happens for frequencies <math>f=\omega/(2\pi)\ll1/(2\pi t_{j})</math>, (<math>t_{j}</math> being the transit time of the ''j''th carrier across the device) because the in time integral of the above equation of the [[Fourier transform]] to be performed to compute the [[Spectral density#Power spectral density|power spectral density]] (PSD) of the noise, the time derivatives provides no contribution. Indeed, according to the Fourier transform, this result derives from integrals such as <math> \int_{0}^{t_{j}}exp(-j\omega t)(\partial Q/\partial t)dt\approx Q(t_{j})-Q(0)</math> , in which <math>Q(t_{j})=Q(0)=0</math>. Therefore, for the PSD computation we can exploit the relationships
:<math>i_{qh}=\sum_{j=1}^{N(t)}q_jv_j\cdot F_h(r_j)=-\sum_{j=1}^{N(t)}q_{j}\frac{d\Phi_{h}[r_{j}(t)]}{dt}=\int_{\Omega}J_{q}\cdot Fd^{3}r</math>
Moreover, as it can be shown,<ref name="note6">Pellegrini, B. (2013), "<math>1/f^{\gamma}</math> noise in graphene", The European Physical Journal B:373-385.</ref> this happens also for <math>f\gg 1/(2\pi t_{j})</math>, for instance when the ''j''th carrier is stored for a long time <math>\tau_{j}</math> in a trap if the screening length due to the other carriers is small in comparison to ''<math>\Omega</math>'' size. All the above considerations hold true for any size of ''<math>\Omega</math>'', including nanodevices. In particular we have a meaningful case when the device is a right parallelepiped or cylinder with <math>S_R</math> as lateral surface and ''u'' as the unit vector along its axis, with the bases <math>S_{E1}</math> and <math>S_{E2}</math> located at a distance ''L'' as electrodes, and with <math>S_{E1}\rightarrow u\rightarrow S_{E2}</math>. Indeed, choosing <math>F_{h}=F=-u/L</math>, from the above equation we finally obtain the current <math>i=i_{1}=i_{q1}=-i_{2}</math>,
:<math>i=\frac{1}{L}\sum_{j=1}^{N(t)}q_{j}v_{ju}=\frac{1}{L}\int_{\Omega}J_{qu}d^{3}r</math> ,
where <math>v_{ju}</math> and <math>J_{qu}</math> are the components of <math>v</math> and <math>J_{q}</math> along <math>u</math>. The above equations in their corpuscular form are particularly suitable for the investigation of transport and noise phenomena from the microscopic point of view, with the application of both the analytical approaches and numerical statistical methods, such as the [[Monte Carlo method|Monte Carlo techniques]]. On the other side, in their collective form of the last terms, they are useful to connect, with a general and new method, the local variations of continuous quantities to the current fluctuation at the device terminals. This will be shown in the next sections.
==Noise==
===Shot noise=== Let us first evaluate the PSD <math>S_S</math> of the [[shot noise]] of the current <math>i=i_{qh}</math> for short circuited device terminals, i.e. when the <math>V_{h}</math>'s are constant, by applying the third member of the first equation of the above Section. To this end, let us exploit the [[Fourier coefficient]]
:<math>D(\omega_{l})\equiv\frac{1}{T^'}\int_{-T^'/2}^{T^'/2}\Delta i(t)\exp(-j\omega_{l}t)dt</math>
and the relationship
:<math>S_{S}(\omega_{l})\equiv\lim_{\Delta f\to 0}\frac{\left \langle D(\omega_l)D^*(\omega_l)\right \rangle}{\Delta f}=\lim_{T^' \to \infty}(2T^'\left \langle D(\omega_l)D^*(\omega_l)\right \rangle)</math>
where <math>\omega_l=l(2\pi /T^')</math>, <math>l=...,-2,-1,1,2,...</math> in the second term and <math>l=1,2,...</math> in the third. If we define with <math>t_{bj}</math> and <math>(t_{bj}+t_j)</math> the beginning and the end of the jth carrier motion inside <math>\Omega</math>, we have either <math>\Phi_h[r_j(t_{bj})]=1</math> and <math>\Phi_h[r_j(t_{bj}+t_j)]=0</math> or vice versa (the case of <math>\Phi_h[r_j(t_{bj})]=\Phi_h[r_j(t_{bj}+t_j)]</math> give no contribution), so that from the first equations of the above and of this Section, we get
:<math>D(\omega_l)\equiv \frac{q}{T^'}(\Delta N^+-\Delta N^-)</math> ,
where <math>N^+ (N^-)</math> is the number of the carriers (with equal charge ''q'') that start from (arrive on) the electrode of interest during the time interval <math>-T^'/2, T^'/2</math>. Finally for <math>\tau_c\ll t_{jmin}</math>, <math>\tau_c</math> being the correlation time, and for carriers with a motion that is statistically independent and a [[Poisson process]] we have <math>\left\langle\Delta N^+\Delta N^-\right \rangle=0</math>, <math>\left\langle\Delta N^+\Delta N^+\right\rangle=\left\langle N^+\right\rangle</math> and <math>\left\langle\Delta N^-\Delta N^-\right\rangle=\left\langle N^-\right\rangle</math> so that we obtain
:<math>S_S=2q(I^++I^-)</math> ,
where <math>I^+ (I^-)</math> is the average current due to the carriers leaving (reaching) the electrode. Therefore, we recover and extend the [[Schottky's theorem]]<ref name=note7>Schottky, W. (1918). "Über spontane stromschwankungen in verschiedenen elektrizitätsleitern". Annalen der Physik 57: 541–567.</ref> on shot noise. For instance for an ideal pn junction, or [[Schottky diode|Schottky barrier diode]], it is <math>I^+=I_0\exp(qv/k_BT)</math>, <math>I^-=I_0</math>, where <math>k_B</math> is the Boltzmann constant, ''T'' the absolute temperature, ''v'' the voltage and <math>I=I^+-I^-</math> the total current. In particular, for <math>v=0</math> the conductance becomes <math>g=(dI/dv)=qI_0/(k_BT)</math> and the above equation gives
:<math>S_S=4k_BTg</math> ,
that is the thermal noise at thermal equilibrium given by the [[Nyquist theorem]].<ref name="note8">Nyquist,H. (1928). Thermal Agitation of Electric Charge in Conductors. Phys. Rev. 32: 110–113.</ref> If the carrier motions are correlated, the above equation has to be changed to the form (for <math>I^+\gg I^-</math>)
:<math>S_S=F_a(2qI)</math> ,
where <math>F_a</math> is the so-called [[Fano factor]] that can be both less than 1 (for instance in the case of carrier generation-recombination in nonideal ''pn'' junctions<ref>Maione, I. A. Pellegrini, B., Fiori, G. Macucci, M. , Guidi, L. and Basso, G.(2011). Shot noise suppression in p-n junctions due to carrier generation-recombination. Phys. Rev. B 83, 155309 –155317.</ref>), and greater than 1 (as in the negative resistance region of resonant-tunneling diode, as a result of the electron-electron interaction being enhanced by the particular shape of the density of states in the well.<ref name=note2 /><ref>Iannaccone, G., Lombardi, G., Macucci, M. and Pellegrini B. (1998), Enhanced shot noise in resonant tunneling: theory and experiment. Phys. Rev. Lett. 80: 1054-1058.</ref>)
===Thermal noise===
Once again from the corpuscular point of view, let us evaluate the [[thermal noise]] with the autocorrelation function <math>\left \langle i(t)i(t+\theta)\right\rangle</math> of <math>i(t)</math> by means of the second term of the second equation of section [[#Fluctuations|Fluctuations]], that for the short circuit condition <math>V_1=V_2=0</math> (i.e., at thermal equilibrium) which implies <math>N(t)=\overline{N}</math>, becomes
:<math>\left \langle i(t)i(t+\theta)\right\rangle=\frac{q^2}{L^2}\sum_{j=1}^{\overline{N}}\left \langle v_{ju}^2(t)\right \rangle_t exp(-\left |\theta\right |/\tau_c)=\frac{q^2\overline{N}k_BT}{L^2m}\exp(-\left |\theta\right |/\tau_c)</math> ,
where ''m'' is the carrier effective mass and <math>\tau_c\ll\tau_{jmin}</math>. As <math>\mu=q\tau_c/[m(1+j\omega)]</math> and <math>G=q\mu\overline{N}/L^2</math> are the carrier mobility and the conductance of the device, from the above equation and the [[Wiener-Khintchine theorem]]<ref name=note12>Wiener, N. (1930), "Generalized Harmonic Analysis", Acta mathematica:118-242.</ref><ref>Khintchine, A.(1934), "Korrelationstheorie der stationären stochastischen Prozesse", Mathematische Annalen 109: 604–615.</ref> we recover the result
:<math>S_T=4k_BT\Re\{G(j\omega)\}</math> ,
obtained by Nyquist from the [[Second law of thermodynamics|second principle of the thermodynamics]], i.e. by means of a macroscopic approach.<ref name="note8" />
===Generation-recombination (g-r) noise===
A significant example of application of the macroscopic point of view expressed by the third term of the second equation of section [[#Fluctuations|Fluctuations]] is represented by the g-r noise generated by the carrier trapping-detrapping processes in device defects. In the case of constant voltages and drift current density <math>J_{qu}=q\mu n_qE, (E\equiv E_u)</math>, that is by neglecting the above velocity fluctuations of thermal origin, from the mentioned equation we get
:<math>i=\frac{1}{L}\int_{\Omega}q\mu n_qEd^3r</math> ,
in which <math>n_q</math> is the carrier density, and its steady state value is <math>\overline{i}\equiv I=q\mu n_qEA</math>, <math>A</math> being the device cross-section surface; furthermore, we use the same symbols for both the time averaged and the instantaneous quantities. Let us first evaluate the fluctuations of the current ''i'', that from the above equation are
:<math>\frac{\Delta i}{I}=\frac{1}{\Omega}(\frac{1}{n_q}\int_{\Omega}\Delta n_qd^3r+\frac{1}{E}\int_{\Omega}\Delta Ed^3r+\frac{1}{\mu}\int_{\Omega}\Delta \mu d^3r)</math> ,
where only the fluctuation terms are time dependent. The mobility fluctuations can be due to the motion or to the change of status of defects that we neglect here. Therefore, we ascribe the origin of g-r noise to the trapping-detrapping processes that contribute to <math>\Delta i</math> through the other two terms via the fluctuation of the electron number <math>\chi=0,1</math> in the energy level <math>\varepsilon_t</math> of a single trap in the channel or in its neighborhood. Indeed, the charge fluctuation <math>q\Delta\chi</math> in the trap generates variations of <math>n_q</math> and of <math>E</math>. However, the variation <math>\Delta E</math> does not contribute to <math>\Delta i</math> because it is odd in the ''u'' direction, so that we get
:<math>\frac{\Delta i}{I}=\frac{1}{\Omega n_q}\int_{\Omega}\Delta n_q d^3r</math> ,
from which we obtain
:<math>\frac{\Delta i}{I}=\frac{1}{\Omega n_q}\int_{\delta\Omega}\Delta n_q ad^3r=-\frac{1}{\Omega n_q}\Delta\chi</math> ,
where the reduction of the integration volume from <math>\Omega</math> to the much smaller one <math>\delta\Omega</math> around the defect is justified by the fact that the effects of <math>\Delta n_q</math> and <math>\Delta E</math> fade within a few multiples of a screening length, which can be small (of the order of nanometers<ref name=note7 /> in [[graphene]]<ref name=note12 />); from [[Gauss's theorem]], we obtain also <math>\int_{\delta\Omega}\Delta n_qd^3r=-\Delta\chi</math> and the r.h.s. of the equation. In it the variation <math>\Delta\chi</math> occurs around the average value <math>\overline{\chi}</math> given by the Fermi-Dirac factor <math>\overline{\chi}\equiv\phi=\{[1+\exp[(\varepsilon_t-\varepsilon_f)/k_B T]\}^{-1}</math>, <math>\varepsilon_f</math> being the [[Fermi level]]. The PSD <math>S_t</math> of the fluctuation <math>\Delta i</math> due to a single trap then becomes <math>S_t/I^2=[1/(\Omega n_q)]^2S_{\chi}</math>, where <math>S_{\chi}=4\phi(1-\phi)\tau/[1+(\omega\tau)^2]</math> is the Lorentzian PSD of the random telegraph signal <math>\chi</math><ref>Machlup, S. (1954), "Noise in semiconductor: spectrum of two parameter random signal", J. Appl. Phys. 25: 341-343.</ref> and <math>\tau</math> is the trap relaxation time. Therefore, for a density <math>n_t</math> of equal and uncorrelated defects we have a total PSD <math>S_{gr}</math> of the g-r noise given by
:<math>S_{gr}=\frac{4I^2n_t\phi(1-\phi)\tau}{\Omega n^2_{q}[1+(\omega\tau)^2]}</math> .
===Flicker noise===
When the defects are not equal, for any distribution of <math>\tau</math> (except a sharply peaked one, as in the above case of g-r noise), and even for a very small number of traps with large <math>\tau</math>, the total PSD <math>S_f</math> of ''i'', corresponding to the sum of the PSD <math>S_t</math> of all the <math>n_t\Omega</math> (statistically independent) traps of the device, becomes<ref>Pellegrini, B. (2000), "A general model of <math>1/f^\gamma</math> noise", Microelectronics Reliability 40: 1775-1780.</ref>
:<math>S_f=\frac{n_tB}{\Omega n_q^2}\frac{I^2}{f^\gamma}</math> ,
where <math>0.85<\gamma<1.15</math> down to the frequency <math>1/2\pi\tau_M</math>, <math>\tau_M</math> being the largest <math>\tau</math> and <math>B(\varepsilon_f/k_B T)</math> a proper coefficient. In particular, for unipolar conducting materials (e.g., for electrons as carriers) it can be <math>n_q\propto exp(\varepsilon_f/k_B T)</math> and, for trap energy levels <math>\varepsilon_t>\varepsilon_f</math>, from <math>S_{\chi}\propto \phi=exp(\varepsilon_f/k_B T)</math> we also have <math>B(\varepsilon_f/k_B T)\propto exp(\varepsilon_f/k_B T)</math>, so that from the above equation we obtain,<ref name="note6" />
:<math>S_f=\frac{\alpha I^2}{N_qf^{\gamma}}</math> ,
where <math>N_q</math> is the total number of the carriers and <math>\alpha</math> is a parameters that depends on the material, structure and technology of the device.
==Extensions==
===Electromagnetic field===
The shown electrokinetics theorem holds true in the 'quasi electrostatic' condition, that is when the vector potential can be neglected or, in other terms, when the squared maximum size of <math>\omega</math> is much smaller than the squared minimum wavelength of the electromagnetic field in the device. However it can be extended to the electromagnetic field in a general form.<ref name="note2" /> In this general case, by means of the displacement current across the surface <math>S_R</math> it is possible, for instance, to evaluate the electromagnetic field radiation from an antenna. It holds true also when the electric permittivity and the [[magnetic permeability]] depend on the frequency. Moreover, the field <math>F(r,t)=-\nabla\Phi</math> other than the electric field in 'quasi electrostatic' conditions, can be any other physical irrotational field.
===Quantum mechanics===
Finally, the electrokinetics theorem holds true in the classical mechanics limit, because it requires the simultaneous knowledge of the position and velocity of the carrier, that is, as a result of the [[uncertainty principle]], when its wave function is essentially non null in a volume smaller than that of device. Such a limit can however be overcome computing the current density according to the quantum mechanical expression.<ref name="note2" /><ref name="note3" />
==Notes==
* Bruno Pellegrini has been the first Electronic Engineering graduate at the University of Pisa, where he is currently Professor Emeritus. He is also author of the [[cut-insertion theorem]], that is at the basis of a novel feedback theory for linear circuits.

{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} [[File:Mangla Dam AerialView.jpg|thumb|240px|right|[[Mangla Dam]].]] The '''[http://www.learningall.com/energy-crisis-in-pakistan/ energy policy of Pakistan]''' is formulated and determined by the federal, provincial, and local institutional entities in [[Pakistan]], which address the issues of energy production, distribution, and consumption of energy, such as gas mileage and petroleum standards.<ref name="Pakistan Today">{{cite news|last=Staff|title=CCI approves National Energy Policy|url=http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2013/08/01/news/national/cci-approves-national-energy-policy/|accessdate=30 August 2013|newspaper=Pakistan Today|date=1 August 2013}}</ref> [[Energy policy]] requires the proper legislation, international treaties, subsidies and incentives to investment, guidelines for [[energy conservation]], [[Taxation in Pakistan|taxation]] and other public policy techniques.
Several mandates and proposals have been called over the years to overlook the energy conservation, such as ''[[Neon signs]] were banned and the official weekend was extended from one to two days in an attempt to conserve electricity'' ([[Yousaf Raza Gillani|Gillani]], 2010)<ref name=geotv /> and ''reducing the electricity load used by [[Industry of Pakistan|industrial units]] by 25% during peak hours'' ([[Shaukat Aziz|Aziz]], 2007),<ref name="AAJ News Archives">{{cite news|last=Staff|title=Shaukat and Jatoi take up energy policy|url=http://www.aaj.tv/2007/05/shaukat-and-jatoi-take-up-energy-policy/|accessdate=30 August 2013|newspaper=AAJ News Archives|date=12 May 2007}}</ref> but no comprehensive long-term energy strategies were implemented. Since 1999, many legislative provisions were adopted for [[energy conservation]] including the seeking energy from various [[Renewable energy in Pakistan|renewable energy sources]]. There is also an intense criticism about the unequal distribution of energy, the irresponsible usage of energy sources, and the country's new plan which is aimed to raise country's [[energy dependence|dependence]] on imported oil for power generation to 50% by 2030.<ref name="The News International, 2008">{{cite news|last=Syed Mohibullah Shah |title=Energized yet powerless |url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-9-71398-Energised-yet-powerless |accessdate=30 August 2013 |newspaper=The News International, 2008 |date=8 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130616163600/http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-9-71398-Energised-yet-powerless |archivedate=16 June 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> After much public criticism, the long-term energy security policy was announced in 2013 through the introduction of equal cutting edge energy transmission network, minimising financial losses across the energy system and aligning the ministries involved in the energy sector as well as improving the governance of energy sources.<ref name="Dawn News, 2013">{{cite news|last=Bhatti|first=Sohail|title=Ambitious' national energy policy formulated|url=http://dawn.com/news/1031108/ambitious-national-energy-policy-formulated|accessdate=30 August 2013|newspaper=Dawn News, 2013|date=22 July 2013}}</ref>
Studies and policy implementation recommended by [[Alternative Energy Development Board|AEDB]], [[Ministry of Water and Power (Pakistan)|Water ministry]] (as policy enforcer), the [[National Electric Power Regulatory Authority|NEPRA]] regulates the energy sources network as well as determining the financial prices of the usage of energy. Government-specific energy-efficiency incentive programs also play a significant role in the overall energy policy of Pakistan. As of 2013 Prime Minister [[Nawaz Sharif]] has announced a determined and aggressive energy policy to meet the energy challenges and energy management.<ref name="Dawn News, 2013"/>
==Energy authorities and institutions== *[[Government of Pakistan]] **[[Ministry of Water and Power (Pakistan)|Ministry of Water and Power]] **[[Alternative Energy Development Board]] *Industrial energy sector **[[Electricity sector in Pakistan]] **[[Electricity in Pakistan]] *Energy and power regulatory authorities **[[Water and Power Development Authority]] **[[National Electric Power Regulatory Authority]] *Energy corporations **[[List of electric supply companies in Pakistan|Electricity and energy corporations in Pakistan]] *[[Karachi Electric]]
==History== In the 1960s, a large civilian energy input and infrastructure was built by the [[Pakistan Armed Forces|Pakistan military]], with the financial funds provided by various countries and international monetary sources.<ref name="Inter-Services Public Relations (ISPR)">{{cite web|last=ISPR|title=A Journey from Scratch to Nuclear Power|work=Govt. Pakistan, ISPR|publisher=Inter-Services Public Relations (ISPR)|accessdate=31 August 2013}}</ref> In the 1960s, much of the energy was produced by the [[Dams in Pakistan|hydroelectric dams]] and [[Thermal power station|thermal]] power stations. In the 1970s, Pakistan's energy consumption expanded to [[nuclear power]] sources with the establishment and commissioning of [[Karachi Nuclear Power Plant|first]] nuclear power station in Karachi. In the 1980s, the dependence on nuclear sources further grew and the [[Pakistan Armed Forces|military]] continued engineering and building the nuclear power infrastructure.
In 1994, Prime Minister [[Benazir Bhutto]] of [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] (PPP) launched the country's first ever and largest [[energy conservation]] program to produce 13,000[[Megawatt|MW]] and issues 70 Memorandum of Understandings (MOUs) and Letters of Intent (LOIs) to Independent Power Producers (IPPs).<ref name="Pakistan Today, August 2013">{{cite news|last=Aziz|first=Sartaj|title=Who is responsible?|url=http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2013/04/23/comment/who-is-responsible-4/|accessdate=30 August 2013|newspaper=Pakistan Today, April 2013|date=23 April 2013}}</ref> This 1994 energy policy brought a decisive shift in Pakistan's diverse energy sources.<ref name="Pakistan Today, August 2013"/> In 1994, out of the total installed capacity of 11000[[Megawatt|MW]], ~60% of energy was produced from the [[Dams in Pakistan|hydroelectric]] power sources while nearly ~40% was produced from the thermal and nuclear sources.<ref name="Pakistan Today, August 2013"/> According to the economic statistics provided by economist, [[Sartaj Aziz]], this mix was reversed from 60:40 to 30:70 in favour of thermal capacity based on imported fuel.<ref name="Pakistan Today, August 2013"/> Every year, this ratio went down further to 20:80 in winter months as hydropower generation was reduced due to lower water flows in the rivers.<ref name="Pakistan Today, August 2013"/>
Controversially, the energy policy depended less on renewable energy sources and dependence on imported oil increased that created a permanent fault in country's [[energy conservation]] system. By 1995, only 27 IPPs were able to generate ~6,335[[Megwatt|MW]] of electricity.<ref name="Pakistan Today, August 2013"/> By 1998, the ratio was stabilised by the policies enforced by Prime Minister [[Nawaz Sharif]]. In 2001, the [[military government (disambiguation)|military government]] led by President [[Pervez Musharraf]] and Prime Minister [[Shaukat Aziz]], while contributing to the growth of domestic demand for electricity through large-scale provision of bank loans for the purchase of air-conditioners and home appliances (share of domestic energy consumption had jumped to 46% of the total by 2008), did not add any new capacity to the energy system.<ref name="Pakistan Today, August 2013"/> In 2012 Pakistan's first wind power installation came online at the [[Jhimpir Wind Energy Project (FFCEL)|FFCEL Wind Energy Project]] in Jhimpir.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nation.com.pk/business/09-Nov-2012/50mw-wind-power-project-connected-to-national-grid|title=50MW wind power project connected to national grid|author=|date=|website=nation.com.pk|accessdate=23 April 2018}}</ref>
==Policy overview==
===Energy policy: 2008–10===
In 2005, Prime Minister [[Shaukat Aziz]] announced the long-term [[energy security]] program which was aimed to the development of the power infrastructure from all energy sources.<ref name="The HIndu">{{cite news|last=Muralidhar Reddy|title=We will oppose domination of Indian Ocean: Shaukat Aziz|url=http://www.hindu.com/2005/03/09/stories/2005030913361200.htm|accessdate=18 November 2013|newspaper=The HIndu|date=8 March 2005}}</ref> This policy relied on [[Privatization in Pakistan|privatising]] the energy sector by international mega energy corporations.<ref name="The News International, 2011"/> Controversially, this program was aimed to raise dependence on imported oil from the [[Arab countries]] for power generation to be increased by 50.1% by 2013.<ref name="The News International, 2011">{{cite news|last=Syed Mohibullah Shah|title=Energised, yet powerless|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=71398&Cat=9|accessdate=18 November 2013|newspaper=The News International, 2011|date=8 October 2011}}</ref>
In 2006, Prime Minister [[Shaukat Aziz|Aziz]] held conversation with the officials of the [[Saudi Arabia|Saudi]] [[Ministry of Petroleum and Mineral Resources of Saudi Arabia|Ministry of Petroleum]] and invited [[Ali Al-Naimi]] to invest in country's energy sector.<ref name="The Dawn News, area studies">{{cite news|last=APP|title=Saudi investment invited in energy, mining sectors|url=http://dawn.com/news/217936/saudi-investment-invited-in-energy-mining-sectors|accessdate=18 November 2013|newspaper=The Dawn News, areastudies|date=7 November 2006<!-- 00:00:00-->}}</ref> In 2007, Prime Minister [[Shaukat Aziz|Aziz]] allocated [[Pakistan Rupee|₨.]] 12.5 billion for power production-related projects which remained unused. In his last policy statement, Prime Minister [[Shaukat Aziz|Aziz]] further called for banning the [[Neon lighting|Neon lights]], [[Neon sign]]s, and to close the market places by 9 pm; such policy enforcement was harshly resisted by the left-wing parties, such as [[Pakistan Peoples Party]], [[Pakistan Communist Party|Communist Party]] and the [[Pakistan Labour Federation|labour unions]].<ref name="Labour Unity Org.">{{cite web|last=Staff |title=Traders agree to close markets at 9 pm |url=https://www.labourunity.org/localnews.php?stpt=2331 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20131020214656/http://www.labourunity.org/localnews.php?stpt=2331 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=20 October 2013 |work=Labour Unity Org. |publisher=Labour Unity Org. |accessdate=18 November 2013 }}</ref>
===Energy Policy: 2010–13===
After the [[Pakistani general election, 2008|general elections]] held in 2008, the mismanagement and weak policies led to an intense repetitive cycle of [[loadshedding]] in the country. Responding to a massive demonstration against the [[loadshedding]] and the growing power shortages in the country, Prime Minister, [[Yousaf Raza Gillani|Yousaf Gilani]] announced the "energy policy" on 22 April 2010.<ref name="BBC1">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8637454.stm|title= Pakistan's PM announces energy policy to tackle crisis|date=22 April 2010|publisher=BBC|accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref>
The policy was announced after the Prime Minister, [[Yousaf Raza Gillani|Gilani]] had held a three-day national energy conference in [[Islamabad]] with energy experts that discussed the causes of the power crisis in [[Pakistan]] and possible steps to relieve it.<ref name="geotv">{{cite news|url=http://www.geo.tv/4-22-2010/63613.htm|title=Steps taken to tackle energy crisis|date=22 April 2010|publisher=[[Geo TV]]|accessdate=23 April 2010}}</ref> On an immediate effects, the gaseous [[Neon lighting|Neon light]]s and the [[Neon sign|signs]] were banned and the official weekend was extended from one to two days in an attempt to conserve electricity.<ref name="nyt04262010">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/27/world/asia/27lahore.html|title=Pakistanis Living on Brink, and Often in the Dark|date=26 April 2010|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=28 April 2010 | first=Sabrina | last=Tavernise}}</ref> Under this policy, several attempts were made by [[Yousaf Raza Gillani|Gilani government]] to [[Privatization in Pakistan|privatise]] the energy sector.<ref name="Prime Minister's Inspection Commission">{{cite web|last1=et. al.|first1=PD|title=Effects of Power Sector Reforms|url=http://pmic.gov.pk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1706&Itemid=612|publisher=Prime Minister's Inspection Commission|accessdate=3 July 2014|year=2013}}</ref> Devised by the Finance Minister [[Abdul Hafeez Shaikh]], the programme failed to resolve electricity shortage, which private energy companies failed to maintain and upgrade despite being part of their contract.<ref name="Prime Minister's Inspection Commission"/> After much criticism and public demonstration in 2012, the [[Pakistan Peoples Party|PPP]] government decided to [[Nationalization in Pakistan|nationalised]] the energy sector and issued clear directives to regulate the energy corporations to produce the power generations.<ref name="Nationalization and Privatization in Pakistan">{{cite web|last1=Amin |first1=Mohd. Ramiz |title=Nationalization and Privatization in Pakistan |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/169855076/Nationalization-and-Privatization-in-Pakistan |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140611063903/http://www.scribd.com/doc/169855076/Nationalization-and-Privatization-in-Pakistan |dead-url=yes |archive-date=11 June 2014 |publisher=Nationalization and Privatization in Pakistan |accessdate=3 July 2014 }}</ref>
===Energy Policy: 2013–18=== [[Musadik Masood Malik]] was appointed Federal Minister, Water and Power of the Pakistan Government in May, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-2-183890-A-caretaker-minister-makes-his-way-into-real-cabinet |title=A caretaker minister makes his way into real cabinet |publisher=Thenews.com.pk |date= |accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref> Within two months, he was replaced by [[Abid Sher Ali]] who served in the role until the ministry was abolished in September, 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/580476/pml-ns-abid-sher-ali-appointed-as-new-state-minister-for-power/|title=PML-N's Abid Sher Ali appointed as new state minister for power|last=|first=|date=22 July 2013|website=The Express Tribune|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In its place a [[Ministry of Energy (Pakistan)|Ministry of Energy]] was created. [[Awais Leghari]] served as the first energy minister of the country until the end of the government's tenure.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://fp.brecorder.com/2017/10/20171005223572/|title=Awais Leghari made Minister of Power Division|last=|first=|date=6 October 2017|website=Business Recorder|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The 2010 amendment to Pakistan’s Constitution (para. 3), empowered each province to formulate the policy framework for the development of public and private sector power generation. This has led to the formation of dedicated provincial departments and empowered public sector companies specialized in renewables to foster and execute power projects through public, private and public–private partnership modes using indigenous power resources.<ref>Asian Development Bank, Access to Clean Energy Investment Program: Summary Sector Assessment: Energy, p.2 </ref>
This tenure's energy policy was aimed at aggressively building power generation capacity through early-harvest projects in [[CPEC]]. A total of 10,973 MW of power was added by the government during its tenure, mostly via private sector investments.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2018/04/12/10973mw-electricity-added-to-national-grid-by-present-govt-na-told/|title=PML-N govt added 10,973MW electricity to system, NA told|website=Pakistan Today|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-05-27}}</ref> In terms of public sector projects conducted by provincial governments in view of the 2010 amendment, KPK government led with the addition of 1,670 MW to the national grid.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1668360/1-pti-claims-govt-added-1670mw-power-grid/|title=PTI claims govt only added 1,670MW to the power grid - The Express Tribune|date=2018-03-24|work=The Express Tribune|access-date=2018-05-27|language=en-US}}</ref> It was followed by Sindh and Punjab governments which contributed 935 MW and 580 MW respectively.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2018/04/23/sindh-contributes-935-mw-wind-energy-in-national-grid-cm/|title=Sindh contributes 935 MW wind energy in national grid: CM|website=Pakistan Today|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-05-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.energy.punjab.gov.pk/_pages/initiatives.html|title=[Initiatives] Energy Department, Govt. of the Punjab, Pakistan|website=www.energy.punjab.gov.pk|access-date=2018-05-27}}</ref> Balochistan government didn't inaugurate any public sector power project during its tenure.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/182491-No-energy-in-Balochistan|title=No energy for Balochistan|last=Baloch|first=Sanaullah|date=29 January 2018|website=The News International|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
However, despite the massive addition of power to the national grid, glaring issues existed in the power sector. There was no viable overhaul done to the electricity transport infrastructure which lead to episodes of plant tripping and extended blackouts during the summer months.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1408040|title=Parts of Punjab, KP hit by massive power breakdown|date=2018-05-16|work=Dawn|access-date=2018-05-27|language=en-US}}</ref> Furthermore, there was still a wide demand and supply gap during high temperature months which led to periodic, planned load-shedding.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180605085134/http://roshanpakistan.pk/pp/|title=Daily Power Position|date=2018-06-04|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref> Finally, the issue of ''circular debt'' was still attached to the power sector and reached a record high of Rs. 922 billion in March, 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1392681|title=Energy sector circular debt touches record Rs922bn|last=Kiani|first=Khaleeq|date=2018-03-02|work=Dawn|access-date=2018-05-27|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Conservation and consumption==
Due to rising demand and a failing power infrastructure severe electricity shortages have occurred in Pakistan. This has led to widespread [[rolling blackout]]s that have paralysed industry and led to protests and rioting.<ref name="BBC1"/> [[Power outage]]s can last 6–8 hours a day in the cities and many more in the rural areas.<ref name="KT">{{cite news|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle08.asp?xfile=data/international/2010/April/international_April1237.xml&section=international|title=Pakistan turns off lights to end energy crisis|date=22 April 2010|work=[[Khaleej Times]]|accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref> According to Mahnaz Parach of Network for Consumer Protection "Children can't do their homework. Housework doesn't get done, as washing machines and other appliances cannot work. When you go home from work, you have no idea whether there will be electricity at home. Your whole life is disturbed."<ref name="Guardian1">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/apr/21/pakistan-energy-shortages-wedding-curfew|title=Pakistan to impose wedding curfew as power shortages cause civil unrest|date=21 April 2010|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=23 April 2010 | location=London | first=Saeed | last=Shah}}</ref>
Experts have warned of an impending energy crisis since 2006.<ref name="dawn07292009">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/2006/07/29/top16.htm |title=Major energy crisis feared |date=29 July 2006 |work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]] |accessdate=24 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090409133544/http://www.dawn.com/2006/07/29/top16.htm |archivedate=9 April 2009 }}</ref> Speaking at a Seminar 'Fueling the Future: Meeting Pakistan's Energy Needs in the 21st Century' held in Washington, D.C. in June 2006 then energy adviser to the prime minister of Pakistan Mukhtar Ahmed stated that the country was taking steps to address the energy shortage.<ref name="dawn06242006">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/2006/06/24/ebr4.htm |title=Pakistan needs to tackle energy crisis |date=24 June 2006 |work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]] |accessdate=24 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725074342/http://www.dawn.com/2006/06/24/ebr4.htm |archivedate=25 July 2008 }}</ref> [[Pakistan Electric Power Company]] estimates that there is a shortage of 6 gigawatts or about 60% of its total generation.<ref name="Dawn2">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/the-newspaper/front-page/19-electricity-shortfall-reaches-6,000mw-840-hh-12|title=Electricity shortfall reaches 6,000MW|date=18 April 2010|work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|accessdate=23 April 2010}}</ref> One of the main reasons of the shortage is thought to be the failure of past governments to anticipate growth in need and the delay in implementation of projects to increase power production. In addition there is widespread power theft and lack of investment in the existing power grid.<ref name="Reuters">{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKSGE63L08920100422|title=Crisis talks as power shortages hit Pakistan industry|date=22 April 2010|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref>
The United States has made improving Pakistan's power infrastructure one of its top priorities.<ref name="Forbes">{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2010/04/22/general-as-pakistan-energy-crisis_7538159.html |title=Pakistan announces measures to save energy |date=22 April 2010 |work=[[Forbes]] |accessdate=22 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100503005638/http://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2010/04/22/general-as-pakistan-energy-crisis_7538159.html |archivedate=3 May 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> US special envoy [[Richard Holbrooke]], while describing the power situation in Pakistan as "unacceptable," has stated that the US would go to its "absolute limits" to help Pakistan overcome the crisis.<ref name="dawn04202010">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/the-newspaper/national/us-will-go-to-absolute-limits-to-help-pakistan-tide-over-energy-crisis-040|title=US to help Pakistan tide over energy crisis|date=20 April 2010|work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|accessdate=24 April 2010}}</ref>
===Power sources and electrical energy === Measures are aimed at cutting consumption by 500 [[megawatt]]s. The official weekend has been extended from one to two days. [[Neon sign]]s and decorative lights have been banned. Power has been cut to government offices by 50% and air conditioners will only be allowed to be switched on after {{Nowrap|11 am}}. Street markets have been asked to close early.<ref name="BBC1"/> Commercial centres except drug stores will be closed at {{Nowrap|8 pm}} and wedding celebrations will be limited to three hours. The government will pay off its {{Nowrap|$1.38 billion}} debt to power producers allowing them to pay fuel suppliers.<ref name="BW1">{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-04-22/pakistan-war-on-power-deficit-to-shut-offices-ban-neon-signs.html|title=Pakistan War on Power Deficit to Shut Offices, Ban Neon Signs|date=22 April 2010|publisher=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]|accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref> Power supply to Pakistan's commercial capital [[Karachi]] will be decreased by 300 megawatts to allow fairer distribution of power to the remaining parts of the country.<ref name="dawn1">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/pakistan/03-energy-crisis-is-not-a-new-phenomenon-gilani-ss-06|title=Gilani vows to reduce load-shedding|date=23 April 2010|work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref> [[Tube well]]s will not be allowed to operate from {{Nowrap|7 pm}} to {{Nowrap|11 pm}}.<ref name="geotv"/> The measures will be reviewed on 30 July 2010.<ref name="TNI">{{cite news|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/top_story_detail.asp?Id=28450|title=Energy conservation strategy announced|date=23 April 2010|work=[[The News International]] |accessdate=23 April 2010}}</ref>
===Consumption by computers=== {{Main|Computing in Pakistan|Green computing}}
Since the early 1990s, the country has observed the highest growth rate in usage of computers that effect the supply of the electricity produced in the system.<ref>{{cite news|title=Computers and its Usage in Pakistan|url=http://propakistani.pk/2008/12/01/computers-and-its-usage-pakistan/|accessdate=3 July 2014|publisher=Pakistan Telecommunications|date=3 December 2008|ref=Pakistan Telecommunications}}</ref> In a survey published by the ''[[Express Tribune]]'', around ~30 million citizens (out of [[Pakistani demographics|180 million]]), uses the internet on daily basis; the internet penetration in the country has reached 16% as of 2013.<ref name="Express Tribune">{{cite news|last1=websedk|title=30m internet users in Pakistan, half on mobile: Report|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/567649/30m-internet-users-in-pakistan-half-on-mobile-report/|accessdate=3 July 2014|agency=Express Tribune|date=24 June 2013}}</ref>
===Variations by regions=== In the days following the announcement, traders in [[Lahore]] rejected the government's decision and kept the markets open after {{Nowrap|8 pm}} in defiance of the ban.<ref name="dawn3">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/pakistan/12-traders+defy+govt+order+of+markets+closure--bi-04|title=Traders defy order of markets' closure|date=23 April 2010|work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|accessdate=23 April 2010}}</ref> Shops were kept open in other cities also after {{Nowrap|8 pm}}. Kashif Shabbir, president of the [[Rawalpindi]] Chamber of Commerce warned the situation would get worse if authorities used force to implement the decision.<ref name="dawn4">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/the-newspaper/front-page/traders-reject-maliks-warning%2C-refuse-to-close-shops-at-8pm-440|title=Traders reject Malik's warning, refuse to close shops at 8 pm|date=24 April 2010|work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|accessdate=24 April 2010}}</ref> There was confusion over implementation of the two-day weekend, and many banks and educational institutions remained open.<ref name="TNIapril24">{{cite news|url=http://thenews.jang.com.pk/updates.asp?id=103562|title=Two holidays: confusion over implementation|date=24 April 2010|work=[[The News International]]|accessdate=24 April 2010}}</ref> Commenting on the defiant mood of the traders, an editorial in ''[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]'' urged everybody to find middle ground.<ref name="dawn04252010">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/the-newspaper/editorial/19-traders-defiance-540-hh-10|title=Traders' defiance|date=25 April 2010|work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|accessdate=25 April 2010}}</ref>
Reacting to the decision to curtail power supply to Karachi, the "City of Lights", leaders of various political parties in the [[Provincial Assembly of Sindh]] condemned the decision and some of them called it "a conspiracy to create a law and order situation." Former [[Nazim of Karachi]], [[Naimatullah Khan]] warned that curtailing the power supply of the city could lead to street battles between protesters and law enforcement.<ref name="dawn04232010">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/the-newspaper/local/karachi/karachi-lights-being-turned-off-to-overcome-energy-crisis-340|title=Karachi lights being turned off to overcome energy crisis|work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|accessdate=24 April 2010}}</ref>
Some analysts have predicted that reduction in the banks' workweek to 5 days will result in revenue losses.<ref name="TNI04252010">{{cite news|url=http://thenews.jang.com.pk/daily_detail.asp?id=235806|title=Two-day weekend to hurt banks' earnings|date=25 April 2010|work=[[The News International]]|accessdate=25 April 2010}}</ref>
The prevailing energy crisis in Pakistan is taking away 2 percent (or Rs 380 billion) of the economy, despite the government has spent Rs 1.1 trillion as subsidies on the sector in the last four-year which accounts for 2.5 percent of the total volume of economy.<ref>[http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-3-111611-Economic-cost-of-energy-crisis-estimated-at-Rs380bn Economic cost of energy crisis estimated at Rs380bn], The News, 1 June 2012</ref>
During June 2012, President [[Asif Ali Zardari]] had said that the government realised the enormity of the challenge of energy shortage and was determined to overcome it in the shortest possible time.<ref>[http://www.geo.tv/GeoDetail.aspx?ID=52017 Disengagement not an option: President Zardari] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120602052044/http://www.geo.tv/GeoDetail.aspx?ID=52017 |date=2 June 2012 }}, Geo News, 1 June 2012</ref>
==International co-operation== Pakistan is already importing small quantity of electricity from [[Iran]] to supply power to [[Gwadar]] town. Pakistan is also actively considering to import electricity from [[India]] and [[Tajikistan]]. [[World Bank]] offered to finance for conducting the feasibility study to import 1200 MW power from India.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://wrmin.nic.in/writereaddata/Inter-StateWaterDisputes/KWDTReport9718468760.pdf|title= Pakistan all set to import electricity from India |year=2014|accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://indianexpress.com/article/business/business-others/adani-mulls-exporting-electricity-to-pakistan/|title= Adani mulls exporting electricity to Pakistan |year=2014|accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref>
Pakistan is also exploring to import [[Piped natural gas|PNG]] via pipe line through [[Wagha]] border from India. India would import the required [[LNG]] and re-gasified LNG (RLNG) would be pumped through its pipelines up to the border point.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://wrmin.nic.in/writereaddata/Inter-StateWaterDisputes/KWDTReport9718468760.pdf|title= India, Pakistan may shake hands on electricity, hydrocarbons|accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref> [[Iran–Pakistan gas pipeline]] is pending for a long time to receive PNG from Iran for the needs of both Pakistan and India.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/indiapakistaniran-pipeline-remains-the-most-viable-option/article5754288.ece|title= India-Pakistan-Iran pipeline remains the most viable option |year=2014|accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Pakistan|Energy}} *[[Effects of global warming on South Asia]] *[[Electricity sector in Pakistan]] *[[Energy crisis]]
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}
==External links== *[http://video.nytimes.com/video/2010/04/26/world/asia/1247467711140/pakistan-s-power-crisis.html Video: Pakistan's Power Crisis], [[The New York Times]], 26 April 2010 *[https://www.youtube.com/user/AlJazeeraEnglish#p/u/38/JiTirXteDu0 Video: Power cuts anger Pakistan traders], [[Al Jazeera English]], 22 April 2010 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100328005536/http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/media-gallery/17-energy-crisis-in-pakistan-ek-01 Energy crisis in Pakistan in Pictures] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100427084031/http://powersave.pk/ PowerSave.pk Awareness Campaign by PEPCO]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.5.3)
revision.text:
'''Enhanced coal bed methane recovery''' is a method of producing additional [[coalbed methane]] from a [[source rock]], similar to [[enhanced oil recovery]] applied to [[oil field]]s. [[Carbon dioxide]] (CO<sub>2</sub>) injected into a [[bituminous coal]] bed would occupy pore space and also [[adsorb]] onto the [[carbon]] in the coal at approximately twice the rate of [[methane]] (CH<sub>4</sub>), allowing for potential enhanced gas recovery.<ref name=Wickstrom>{{cite web |url=http://www.dnr.state.oh.us/Portals/10/pdf/BurgerReport.pdf |title=Geologic Assessment of the Burger Power Plant and Surrounding Vicinity for Potential Injection of Carbon Dioxide |first=Lawrence H. |last=Wickstrom |author2=Ernie R. Slucher |author3=Mark T. Baranoski |author4=Douglas J. Mullett |publisher=Ohio Geological Survey |year=2008 |accessdate=2008-06-21 |location=Columbus, Ohio |id=Open-File Report 2008-1 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081231180506/http://www.dnr.state.oh.us/Portals/10/pdf/BurgerReport.pdf |archivedate=2008-12-31 |df= }}</ref> This technique may be used in conjunction with [[carbon capture and storage]] in [[mitigation of global warming]] where the carbon dioxide that is [[CO2 sequestration|sequestered]] is captured from the output of [[fossil fuel power plant]]s.
A research project at [[ETH Zurich]] is studying the process of pumping carbon dioxide into unminable coal seams and recovering the methane that is subsequently displaced.
An extensive experimental investigation about the process of desorbing methane by adsorbing carbon dioxide in real coal samples was performed. The proof of principle and the technical feasibility of the method could be verified with these measurements. These research results indicate that CBM can become an alternative to conventional natural gas. ECBM provides additional to CBM the advantage of long-term CO2 storage in the underground coal seams.<ref>[http://www.rubotherm.com/investigation-of-enhanced-coal-bed-methane-ecbm-processes.html ''Investigation of Enhanced Coal Bed Methane (ECBM) Processes - Gravimetric Adsorption Measurements under Realistic Conditions''] </ref>
However, without other incentives, enhanced coal bed methane recovery is not economical as the commercial value of the released methane does not completely offset the cost of pumping.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ipe.ethz.ch/laboratories/spl/research/adsorption/project03 |title=ETH - SPL - Enhanced coal bed methane recovery |date=2006-08-31 |publisher=[[ETH Zurich]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706232006/http://www.ipe.ethz.ch/laboratories/spl/research/adsorption/project03 |archivedate=2011-07-06 |df= }}</ref>
Penetration of CO<sub>2</sub> into coal is simulated using a stress-enhanced diffusion model.<ref>F. J. Vermolen, M.G. Gharasoo, P. L. J. Zitha, J. Bruining. (2009). Numerical Solutions of Some Diffuse Interface Problems: The Cahn-Hilliard Equation and the Model of Thomas and Windle.'' IntJMultCompEng'','''7(6)''':523–543.</ref><ref>A. Mikelić and J. Bruining. (2008). Analysis of Model Equations for Stress-Enhanced Diffusion in Coal Layers. Part I: Existence of a Weak solution. ''SIAM J. Math. Anal.'','''40''':1671-1691</ref>
==See also== * [[Coal bed methane extraction]] * [[Global Methane Initiative]]
==Further reading == * Reznik, A., Singh, P. K., and Foley, W. L., 1982, An analysis of the effect of carbon dioxide injection on the recovery of in-situ methane from bituminous coal: An experimental simulation: Society of Petroleum Engineers/U.S. Department of Energy 10822 * Gale, J., and Freund, P., 2001, Coal-bed methane enhancement with CO<sub>2</sub> sequestration worldwide potential: Environmental Geosciences, v. 8, no. 3, p. 210–217. * Schroeder, K., Ozdemir, E., and Morsi, B.I., 2002, Sequestration of carbon dioxide in coal seams: Journal of Energy and Environmental Research, v. 2, no. 1. p. 54–63. (from U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory, First National Conference on Carbon Sequestration, 2001).
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

{{noref|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox ecoregion | name = Euxine-Colchic deciduous forests | image = Uzunbudzhak.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = An Euxine forest in [[Strandzha Nature Park]], southern-eastern [[Bulgaria]] | country = [[Bulgaria]] | country1 = [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] | country2 = [[Turkey]] | area = 74330 | biome = [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forests]] | map = Ecoregion PA0422.png | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = Euxine-Colchic deciduous forests ecoregion along the southern coast of Black Sea, shown in yellow. }} The '''Euxine-Colchic deciduous forests''' [[terrestrial ecoregion|ecoregion]], in the [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forests]] [[Biome]], is located along the southern shore of the [[Black Sea]]. The ecoregion extends along the thin coastal strip from the southeastern corner of [[Bulgaria]] in the west, to [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] in the east, across the northern coast of [[Turkey]], where it wraps around the eastern end of the Black Sea.
==Sub-regions== The ecoregion is divided into two sub-regions, chiefly based on the amount of precipitation.
The understory of evergreen mesomorphic broadleaf shrubs is characteristic for both sub-regions. Notable species in the understory include various rhododendrons such as Pontic rhododendron (''[[Rhododendron ponticum]]''); Black Sea holly (''[[Ilex colchica]]''), cherry laurel (''[[Laurocerasus officinalis]]''), Caucasus (''[[Buxus colchica]]'') and common box (''[[Buxus sempervirens]]''), Caucasian whortleberry (''[[Vaccinium arctostaphylos]]''), etc. From a European perspective, the majority of these count as [[relict species]] from the [[Tertiary]] period. [[File:Zelenika Rhododendron Ponticum.jpg|thumb|An understory of evergreen shrubs like the [[Pontic rhododendron]] is characteristic for the Euxine-Colchic deciduous forests ecoregion]]
===Colchian forests=== The '''Colchic''' or '''Colchian forests''' are found around the southeast corner of the Black Sea in Turkey and Georgia in [[Machakhela National Park]] and area around it. The Colchian forests are mixed, with deciduous [[Alnus glutinosa|Black Alder]] ''(Alnus glutinosa)'', hornbeam (''[[Carpinus betulus]]'' and ''[[Carpinus orientalis|C. orientalis]]''), [[Oriental Beech]] (''Fagus orientalis''), and [[Sweet Chestnut]] ''(Castanea sativa)'', together with evergreen [[Nordmann Fir]] (''Abies nordmanniana'', the tallest tree in Europe at 78m), [[Caucasian Spruce]] (''Picea orientalis'') and [[Scots Pine]] (''Pinus sylvestris''). The Colchic region has high rainfall, averaging 1,500-2,500 mm annually, with a maximum in excess of 4,000 mm, and is home to some of Europe's [[temperate rain forests]].
===Euxinic forests=== The drier '''Euxine''' or '''Euxinic forests''' lie west of the [[Melet River]], and extend across the [[Bosporus]] along the Black Sea coast of European Turkey to Bulgaria. The Euxine forests receive an average of 1,000 to 1,500 mm precipitation annually. The Bulgarian part of the ecoregion lies within [[Strandzha Nature Park]], where it borders on and transitions into the [[Balkan mixed forests]] ecoregion.
Rare habitat types include [[dune|coastal sand dunes]] and [[peatland]]s.
==See also== *[[:Category:Forests of Turkey|Forests of Turkey]] *[[Black Sea Region|Northern Anatolia—Black Sea Region]] — ''of Asian Turkey''. *[[Machakhela National Park]] *[[Mtirala National Park]] *[[Kintrishi Protected Landscape]]
==External links== * {{WWF ecoregion|name=Euxine-Colchic deciduous forests|id=pa0422}}
{{-}} {{Paleartic temperate broadleaf and mixed forests}}

'''Forest management''' is a [[Topic outline of forestry#Branches of forestry|branch]] of [[forestry]] concerned with overall administrative, economic, legal, and social aspects, as well as scientific and technical aspects, such as [[silviculture]], [[forest protection|protection]], and forest regulation. This includes management for [[aesthetics]], [[fish]], [[outdoor recreation|recreation]], urban values, [[watershed management|water]], [[wilderness]], [[wildlife]], [[forest product|wood products]], [[forest genetic resources]], and other [[Nontimber forest products|forest resource values]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Glossary of Forestry Terms in British Columbia | publisher = Ministry of Forests and Range (Canada) | date = March 2008| url = http://www.for.gov.bc.ca/hfd/library/documents/glossary/Glossary.pdf | format = pdf | accessdate = 2009-04-06}}</ref> Management can be based on conservation, economics, or a mixture of the two. Techniques include [[Lumber|timber]] extraction, [[Afforestation|planting]] and [[Reforestation|replanting]] of various [[Tree|species]], cutting roads and pathways through forests, and preventing [[Wildfire|fire]].
==Definition==
The forest is a natural system that can supply different products and services. The working of this system is influenced by the natural environment: climate, topography, soil, etc., and also by human activity. The actions of humans in forests constitute forest management.{{cn|date=May 2016}} In developed societies, this management tends to be elaborate and planned in order to achieve the objectives that are considered desirable.{{cn|date=May 2016}}
Some forests have been and are managed to obtain traditional forest products such as firewood, fiber for paper, and timber, with little thinking for other products and services. Nevertheless, as a result of the progression of environmental awareness, management of forests for multiple use is becoming more common.<ref name=Young>{{cite book |last1=Young |first1=Raymond |title=Introduction to Forest Science |date=1982 |publisher=John Wiley & sons |isbn=978-0471064381|page=207}}</ref>
==Public input and awareness== There has been increased public awareness of natural resource policy, including forest management.{{cn|date=May 2018}} Public concern regarding forest management may have shifted from the extraction of timber for earning money for the economy, to the preservation of additional forest [[natural resources|resources]], including [[wildlife]] and [[old growth forest]], protecting [[biodiversity]], [[drainage basin|watershed]] management, and [[recreation]]. Increased environmental awareness may contribute to an increased public mistrust of forest management professionals.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Shindler |first=Bruce |authorlink= |author2=Lori A. Cramer |date= January 1999 |title=Shifting Public Values for Forest Management: Making Sense of Wicked Problems |journal=Western Journal of Applied Forestry |volume=14 |issue=1 |pages=28–34 |issn=0885-6095 |pmid= |pmc= |doi= |bibcode= |oclc= |id= |url=http://www.fs.fed.us/eco/eco-watch/wickedpr.html |language= |accessdate=2008-08-25 |laysummary= |laysource= |laydate= |quote= }}</ref> But it can also lead to greater understanding about what professionals do for forests for nature conservation and ecological services. The importance of taking care of the forests for ecological as well as economical sustainable reasons has been shown in the TV show [[Ax Men]].
Many tools like [[GIS]] and [[photogrammetry]]<ref>[http://bib.irb.hr/datoteka/599104.BALENOVIC_ET_AL_-_COMPARISON_OF_CLASSICAL_TERRESTRIALPDF I. Balenovich, A. Seletkovich, et al. Comparison of Classical Terrestrial and Photogrammetric Method in Creating Management Division. FORMEC. Croatia 2012. pp. 1-13.]</ref><ref>[http://www.seefor.eu/images/arhiva/vol2_no2/03_balenovic.pdf I. Balenović, D. Vuletić, et al. Digital Photogrammetry – State of the Art and Potential for Application in Forest Management in Croatia. SEEFOR. South-East European Forestry. #2, 2011. pp. 81–93.]</ref> modelling have been developed to improve [[forest inventory]] and management planning.<ref>[http://sapiens.revues.org/index734.html Mozgeris, G. (2008) “The continuous field view of representing forest geographically: from cartographic representation towards improved management planning”. ''S.A.P.I.EN.S.'' '''1''' (2) ]</ref> Since 1953, the volume of standing trees in the United States have increased by 90% due to sustainable forest management.<ref>[https://www.contractorstoday.com/the-value-of-hardwood-floors The Value of Hardwood Floors]</ref>
==Wildlife considerations== The abundance and diversity of birds, mammals, amphibians and other wildlife are affected by strategies and types of forest management.<ref>* Philip Joseph Burton. 2003. ''Towards sustainable management of the boreal forest'' 1039 pages</ref>
==Management intensity==
Forest management varies in intensity from a leave alone, natural situation to a highly intensive regime with silvicultural interventions. Forest Management is generally increased in intensity to achieve either economic criteria (increased timber yields, [[non-timber forest product]]s, [[ecosystem services]]) or ecological criteria (species recovery, fostering of rare species, carbon sequestration).<ref>Classification of Forest Management Approaches: A New Conceptual Framework and Its Applicability to European Forestry
Philipp S. Duncker 1, Susana M. Barreiro 2, Geerten M. Hengeveld 3, Torgny Lind 4, William L. Mason 5, Slawomir Ambrozy 6 and Heinrich Spiecker 1|http://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol17/iss4/art51/</ref>
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Biodiversity]] * [[Certified wood]] * [[Community forestry]] * [[Conservation biology]] * [[Coppicing]] * [[Edmund Zavitz]] * [[Environmental protection]] * [[Even-aged timber management]] * [[Forest farming]] * [[Forest informatics]] * [[Forest inventory]] * [[Forest plans]] * [[Growth and yield modelling]] * [[Habitat conservation]] * [[Healthy Forests Initiative]] * [[Natural environment]] * [[Natural landscape]] * [[Nature]] * [[Outline of forestry]] * [[Overexploitation]] * [[Renewable resource]] * [[Sustainability]] * [[Sustainable development]] * [[Sustainable forest management]] * [[Van Vigyan Kendra|Van Vigyan Kendra (VVK)]] Forest Science Centres {{div col end}} {{br}}
==References== [[Image:Amazonie deforestation.jpg|thumb|right|230px|[[Deforestation]] and increased road-building in the [[Amazon Rainforest]] are a significant concern because of increased human encroachment upon wild areas, increased resource extraction and further threats to [[biodiversity]].]] {{Reflist}}
{{Forestry}} {{Authority control}} {{Portal bar|Forestry|Environment|Ecology|Earth sciences|Biology|Sustainable development}}
